column1: Summarize the discussion about the efficacy of the law.|Barry Hughes first stated that children had fewer rights than adults and therefore the law should be enforced to defend physical assault. As such social behavior was not available now
column2: the law should change to reflect that. The discussion then turned to talk about the legal framework and its prosecution.|"[""Barry Hughes: I think the law should reflect contemporary society and the law is evolutionary in nature
column3: and should be evolutionary in nature. And just as if we go back 50 years there are types of behaviour that we might all have contemplated back then as being socially acceptable
column4: many of those types of behaviour are not now
column5: and the law has changed to reflect that. We don't need to go back a very long way to find
column6: for example
column7: that there was no such offence as raping one's married wife
column8: and the law has changed to reflect the fact that that is simply not acceptable. And from what I've seen of the research
column9: and I think back to the 2007 review
column10: to which you've just referred
column11: there is evidence within that review already that opinions are changing. And I've seen research more current than that that suggests that young people find it less acceptable to use reasonable punishment in chastising a child than do people of an older generation. Of course
column12: as we move forward in time
column13: the people who are young now are going to be the older adults of the future. So one would hope that the law will change to reflect the way in which people behave within society.""
column14: ""Barry Hughes: I think we would need to update the guidance
column15: and it goes back to the application of the evidential stage
column16: before the public interest stage. On the evidential stage
column17: I doubt that we'll need to do much
column18: other than to make people aware that the defence is not available in Wales in the same way that it is in England
column19: and we might have some light-touch guidance around that. When it comes to the public interest stage
column20: that's a little more specialist and I think we would need to develop more with respect to that.""

column35: I'm probably being unfair to myself. I think most staff would probably be aware that we are involved in this and that it is something that

column1: Barry Hughes: I think the law should reflect contemporary society and the law is evolutionary in nature
column2: and should be evolutionary in nature. And just as if we go back 50 years there are types of behaviour that we might all have contemplated back then as being socially acceptable
column3: many of those types of behaviour are not now
column4: and the law has changed to reflect that. We don't need to go back a very long way to find
column5: for example
column6: that there was no such offence as raping one's married wife
column7: and the law has changed to reflect the fact that that is simply not acceptable. And from what I've seen of the research
column8: and I think back to the 2007 review
column9: to which you've just referred
column10: there is evidence within that review already that opinions are changing. And I've seen research more current than that that suggests that young people find it less acceptable to use reasonable punishment in chastising a child than do people of an older generation. Of course
column11: as we move forward in time
column12: the people who are young now are going to be the older adults of the future. So one would hope that the law will change to reflect the way in which people behave within society.

column1: Barry Hughes: I think we would need to update the guidance
column2: and it goes back to the application of the evidential stage
column3: before the public interest stage. On the evidential stage
column4: I doubt that we'll need to do much
column5: other than to make people aware that the defence is not available in Wales in the same way that it is in England
column6: and we might have some light-touch guidance around that. When it comes to the public interest stage
column7: that's a little more specialist and I think we would need to develop more with respect to that.

column1: Dawn Bowden AM: And are you satisfied that your staff in Wales—well
column2: and in England
column3: actually
column4: across the border—will be sufficiently aware of the divergence in this area of law?

column1: Barry Hughes: Not as of the present day. Give us a chance. [Laughter.]
Dawn Bowden AM: But you would expect that to be something you would—

column2: I have no doubt. To an extent
column3: actually
column4: I think I would say that staff in Wales are aware of this already
column5: because in my role as chief Crown prosecutor
column6: I publish a monthly blog and we talk about the things we're doing
column7: so staff are aware. I've discussed with staff and they've seen my blog and we've put it on our website: there have been engagements with the Welsh Government that this is a piece of work in which we're interested and that is under way. So
column8: actually
column9: I'm probably being unfair to myself. I think most staff would probably be aware that we are involved in this and that it is something that
column10: at present
column11: may well happen.

column1: Dawn Bowden AM: Okay. And does that mean that there would also be a similar need for the CPS in England to be aware of the changes?

column2: that's really helpful
column3: thank you.

column1: What was the two-stage test during prosecutions when discussing the efficacy of the law?|The first stage was to check whether there was sufficient evidence submitted by the police to provide a realistic prospect of conviction. Only if the first stage was satisfied, the second stage came to be considered, which was in the public interest.|[""Lynne Neagle AM: Just before you move on
column2: can I ask you a question? This morning the committee was meeting with groups of parents who are opposed to the Bill and groups of parents who are for the Bill
column3: and one of the parents this morning was querying where the interests of the child would come into the public interest test. Now
column4: I've looked at the code and there is a section about impact on the victim. Can you just clarify for the record how the best interests of the child would be taken into account in considering whether to go forward with a prosecution?""
column5: ""Barry Hughes: I have to say I think that extremely unlikely. In the CPS
column6: we don't have targets for securing convictions or not. Clearly
column7: we prosecute if we think that there's a reasonable prospect
column8: a realistic prospect
column9: of conviction and it's in the public interest
column10: but we have no targets. And I would also say
column11: because the numbers here are likely to be so small
column12: any assertion of looking to meet targets—it's a tiny
column13: tiny fragment of a drop in the ocean.""
column14: 'Sian Gwenllian AM: What about—? There is a target for unsolved crimes
column15: or unsolved offences. What if they fall into that category? Is that an unintended consequence?'
column16: ""Barry Hughes: I'm talking about something I don't have great knowledge of here. There was
column17: at one stage
column18: a series of targets for the police that bore down upon cases that secure what was called a sanction detection
column19: which counted for Home Office figures. That disappeared some years ago. Some individual constabularies may still have targets
column20: but
column21: as far as I'm aware
column22: we don't have a suite of national measures. The police are required to report against this
column23: but we don't have targets. And
column25: the police are much more sensible these days than they may have been 20 years ago
column26: in terms of trying to get cases charged in order to meet some notional target. It's much less of an issue than it ever was—much.""]"|"You are an assistant that answers questions about meeting transcripts.

column1: Lynne Neagle AM: Just before you move on
column2: can I ask you a question? This morning the committee was meeting with groups of parents who are opposed to the Bill and groups of parents who are for the Bill
column3: and one of the parents this morning was querying where the interests of the child would come into the public interest test. Now
column4: I've looked at the code and there is a section about impact on the victim. Can you just clarify for the record how the best interests of the child would be taken into account in considering whether to go forward with a prosecution?

column1: Barry Hughes: I have to say I think that extremely unlikely. In the CPS
column2: we don't have targets for securing convictions or not. Clearly
column3: we prosecute if we think that there's a reasonable prospect
column4: a realistic prospect
column5: of conviction and it's in the public interest
column6: but we have no targets. And I would also say
column7: because the numbers here are likely to be so small
column8: any assertion of looking to meet targets—it's a tiny
column9: tiny fragment of a drop in the ocean.

column1: Sian Gwenllian AM: What about—? There is a target for unsolved crimes
column2: or unsolved offences. What if they fall into that category? Is that an unintended consequence?

column1: Barry Hughes: I'm talking about something I don't have great knowledge of here. There was
column2: at one stage
column3: a series of targets for the police that bore down upon cases that secure what was called a sanction detection
column4: which counted for Home Office figures. That disappeared some years ago. Some individual constabularies may still have targets
column5: but
column6: as far as I'm aware
column7: we don't have a suite of national measures. The police are required to report against this
column8: but we don't have targets. And
column9: in my experience
column10: the police are much more sensible these days than they may have been 20 years ago
column11: in terms of trying to get cases charged in order to meet some notional target. It's much less of an issue than it ever was—much.

column1: Summarize the discussion about the divergence between the law in England and Wales.|Barry Hughes indicated that the Bill would impact England and their people, although it needed a period. Moreover, Barry thought there was no cross-border issue from the potential legislation, and the draft changing to CPS guidance would not be helpful for scrutinisers to decide on the law in Wales.|[""Barry Hughes: If this Bill goes through
column2: then it will remove a defence
column3: which will make it likely that the police will give this more consideration for referral to the CPS than beforehand
column4: but it doesn't necessarily mean they will refer it
column5: because it will depend on the facts of each individual case.""

column1: Lynne Neagle AM: We've got some questions now on the divergence between the law in England and Wales from Dawn Bowden.

column1: What did Barry Hughes think about the implications for implementing the Bill in Wales when talking about the divergence between the law in England and Wales?|Barry Hughes concluded two kinds of implications. First, the Bill would raise awareness for people from England who travel to Wales. column13: and then officials on both sides have been engaging with each other. It hasn't been a very close-knit involvement
column14: but we have had enough involvement so that we've felt we've been able to offer views on how we would deal with the legislation.""

column1: Dawn Bowden AM: And that would be primarily around the public interest issue.

Dawn Bowden AM: I understand. Okay. So you're obviously a key stakeholder in terms of this legislation and you're clearly very au fait with it and all its implications. What's actually been your involvement with the Government as they've been developing this legislation?
Barry Hughes: My own personal involvement?
Dawn Bowden AM: Or the service's.
Barry Hughes: Iwan and colleagues have had some involvement on a more routine basis. I met with a Minister and a Deputy Minister—I met with Huw Irranca-Davies a little while ago
column2: and I met with Julie Morgan a few months ago—to discuss the overall implications
column3: and then officials on both sides have been engaging with each other. It hasn't been a very close-knit involvement
column4: but we have had enough involvement so that we've felt we've been able to offer views on how we would deal with the legislation.

column1: Dawn Bowden AM: Okay. So you've been satisfied with the level of involvement that you've had.
Barry Hughes: Yes. I don't feel that it's been too much
column2: nor do I feel we've been left on the side at all.

column1: Barry Hughes: I think we would need to update the guidance

column1: Suzy Davies AM: Okay. And what about afterwards
column2: then? Because one of the pieces of thinking behind this Act is to collect data to see whether this change in the law actually works. Do you want to talk us through a little bit about how that might affect you? I don't know who to ask on this.

column3: we do this through our case management system

column11: unbelievably; it wouldn't happen. So
column12: we would keep a manual log of every referral. That would be unmanageable if we were dealing with hundreds and hundreds of cases.

column1: Summarize the discussion about out-of-court disposals.|Barry Hughes introduced their cooperated organizations the National Police Chiefs' Council and their work on the out-of-court disposals. Then, Hughes and Vikki Howells talked about the possibility of creating a body of out-of-court disposals specific to the Bill. Lastly, there was a short discussion about the duty around awareness raising.|['Lynne Neagle AM: Thank you. Vikki.'
column2: ""Vikki Howells AM: Thank you. I've got one further series of questions around out-of-court disposals
column3: which you've already mentioned briefly. In your written evidence
column4: you say there's ongoing work exploring diversion rather than prosecution in respect of this Bill. Firstly
column5: could you tell us a bit more about the work that is being done to explore this as an option?""
column6: ""Barry Hughes: We've been working with the National Police Chiefs' Council. Their lead is deputy chief constable Sara Glen. She is responsible for developing the police approach to out-of-court disposals and simplifying the range of out-of-court disposals. There is quite a range
column7: and life would be simpler and clearer to have fewer types of disposal with more clarity about what each one of them involved. I must say
column8: this is primarily a matter for the police
column9: because there are a great many offences or reports of crime that do not reach the CPS because they are dealt with by way of an out-of-court disposal. Any case that the police refer to us for a charging decision is going to be something—. There's a document called the director's guidance on charging
column10: which is issued by the director of public prosecutions
column11: which sets out offences the police may charge and offences the CPS may charge. Offences that the police refer to us for a charging decision will generally be offences where they feel that there should be a prosecution rather than an out-of-court disposal. There may be cases where it's genuinely very difficult to assess what's the best approach
column12: in which case we will have a conversation with them
column13: a meaningful conversation
column14: about what's the best way to approach that particular case. There will also be cases
column15: and we see these not that rarely
column16: where the police will bring a case to us for a prosecution on the basis that satisfies the evidential stage and satisfies the public interest stage
column17: and we take a different view on the public interest stage. So
column19: it involves a 15-year-old youth—we\xa0 think that diversion from the criminal justice system is a better disposal and we decide not to prosecute. We aren't responsible for administering\xa0the out-of-court disposal or indeed monitoring compliance with that disposal
column20: if
column21: for example
column22: it has conditions attached
column23: such as repayment of the damage caused to a window or a front gate. That's not our responsibility—that will fall to the police—but we can decide that an out-of-court disposal is a more appropriate disposal than a prosecution. Does that help?""
column24: ""Barry Hughes: The way I might see it is that
column26: policing's not devolved
column27: the CPS is not devolved—the way I might see this is that
column29: you could build an infrastructure that provides for a range of out-of-court disposals. You can't direct the police or the CPS to point people towards that
column31: if you build a good infrastructure
column32: it's more likely that people will be pointed in that direction.""
column33: ""Barry Hughes: Somewhere within Wales—Welsh Government
column35: the police working in partnership. It may be that the police and crime commissioners use some of their commissioning powers to work something up. I'm not the right person to answer that question.""
column38: ""Lynne Neagle AM: Thank you. If I could just ask about awareness raising
column39: then: you mentioned the Bill in Scotland
column40: but that Bill includes a duty on the Government to raise awareness of the change. There's no such duty proposed in this Bill. Do you think that's right or should this committee be saying that there should be a similar duty imposed in Wales?""
column41: ""Barry Hughes: I'm not sure it's for me to say whether there should be a duty or not. I can
column42: however
column43: say that I think the greater the level of awareness
column44: the more likely it is that the Act
column50: you mentioned the fact that there's no indication of any plans for awareness raising in England and that if a person from England is being prosecuted in Wales as a result of this change
column51: a question could arise about the lack of knowledge about the different provisions that apply in Wales. Can I ask what approach the CPS currently takes in Wales if a law is unintentionally broken by someone who's come from outside the UK
column53: ""Barry Hughes: It's straightforward: if someone comes to this country and commits an offence here—by this country
column54: I'd say England or Wales; I'd treat them as one for these purposes—if someone comes from abroad and commits an offence that isn't an offence in their country
column56: then I'm afraid that ignorance of the law is no defence. So
column59: and I was pleased to see
column60: that the media publicity surrounding this proposed legislation
column62: reached as far afield as New York and had widespread media coverage across England and Wales
column63: and I think the Government would be well placed here to take advantage of that willingness of the media to explore something
column65: and I think you've probably seen some of that. Anything like that is a good story
column66: and a good story gets out there
column67: which means you're more likely to make people aware of it.""]"|"You are an assistant that answers questions about meeting transcripts.

column1: Lynne Neagle AM: Thank you. Vikki.
Vikki Howells AM: Thank you. I've got one further series of questions around out-of-court disposals
column2: which you've already mentioned briefly. In your written evidence
column3: you say there's ongoing work exploring diversion rather than prosecution in respect of this Bill. Firstly
column4: could you tell us a bit more about the work that is being done to explore this as an option?

column1: Barry Hughes: We've been working with the National Police Chiefs' Council. Their lead is deputy chief constable Sara Glen. She is responsible for developing the police approach to out-of-court disposals and simplifying the range of out-of-court disposals. There is quite a range
column2: and life would be simpler and clearer to have fewer types of disposal with more clarity about what each one of them involved. I must say
column3: this is primarily a matter for the police
column4: because there are a great many offences or reports of crime that do not reach the CPS because they are dealt with by way of an out-of-court disposal. Any case that the police refer to us for a charging decision is going to be something—. There's a document called the director's guidance on charging
column5: which is issued by the director of public prosecutions
column6: which sets out offences the police may charge and offences the CPS may charge. Offences that the police refer to us for a charging decision will generally be offences where they feel that there should be a prosecution rather than an out-of-court disposal. There may be cases where it's genuinely very difficult to assess what's the best approach
column7: in which case we will have a conversation with them
column8: a meaningful conversation
column9: about what's the best way to approach that particular case. There will also be cases
column10: and we see these not that rarely
column11: where the police will bring a case to us for a prosecution on the basis that satisfies the evidential stage and satisfies the public interest stage
column12: and we take a different view on the public interest stage. So
column13: we might say—for example
column14: it involves a 15-year-old youth—we  think that diversion from the criminal justice system is a better disposal and we decide not to prosecute. We aren't responsible for administering the out-of-court disposal or indeed monitoring compliance with that disposal
column16: for example
column17: it has conditions attached
column18: such as repayment of the damage caused to a window or a front gate. That's not our responsibility—that will fall to the police—but we can decide that an out-of-court disposal is a more appropriate disposal than a prosecution. Does that help?

column1: Barry Hughes: The way I might see it is that
column2: clearly
column3: policing's not devolved
column4: the CPS is not devolved—the way I might see this is that
column5: within Wales
column6: you could build an infrastructure that provides for a range of out-of-court disposals. You can't direct the police or the CPS to point people towards that
column7: but
column8: if you build a good infrastructure
column9: it's more likely that people will be pointed in that direction.

column1: Barry Hughes: Somewhere within Wales—Welsh Government
column2: local authorities
column3: the police working in partnership. It may be that the police and crime commissioners use some of their commissioning powers to work something up. I'm not the right person to answer that question.

column1: Vikki Howells AM: Okay. Thank you
column2: Chair.

column1: Lynne Neagle AM: Thank you. If I could just ask about awareness raising
column2: then: you mentioned the Bill in Scotland
column3: but that Bill includes a duty on the Government to raise awareness of the change. There's no such duty proposed in this Bill. Do you think that's right or should this committee be saying that there should be a similar duty imposed in Wales?

column1: Barry Hughes: I'm not sure it's for me to say whether there should be a duty or not. I can
column2: however
column3: say that I think the greater the level of awareness
column4: the more likely it is that the Act
column5: if passed
column6: will achieve its intentions.

column2: thank you. And
column3: in your written evidence
column4: you mentioned the fact that there's no indication of any plans for awareness raising in England and that if a person from England is being prosecuted in Wales as a result of this change
column5: a question could arise about the lack of knowledge about the different provisions that apply in Wales. Can I ask what approach the CPS currently takes in Wales if a law is unintentionally broken by someone who's come from outside the UK
column6: for example?

column1: Barry Hughes: It's straightforward: if someone comes to this country and commits an offence here—by this country
column2: I'd say England or Wales; I'd treat them as one for these purposes—if someone comes from abroad and commits an offence that isn't an offence in their country
column3: but is an offence here
column4: then I'm afraid that ignorance of the law is no defence. So
column5: raising awareness is important
column6: and I saw
column7: and I was pleased to see
column8: that the media publicity surrounding this proposed legislation
column9: which is now going through
column10: reached as far afield as New York and had widespread media coverage across England and Wales
column11: and I think the Government would be well placed here to take advantage of that willingness of the media to explore something
column12: which is potentially divisive
column13: and I think you've probably seen some of that. Anything like that is a good story
column14: and a good story gets out there
column15: which means you're more likely to make people aware of it.

column3: the police working in partnership. It may be that the police and crime commissioners use some of their commissioning powers to work something up. I'm not the right person to answer that question.

column1: Vikki Howells AM: Okay. Thank you
column2: Chair.

column1: Lynne Neagle AM: Thank you. If I could just ask about awareness raising
column2: then: you mentioned the Bill in Scotland
column3: but that Bill includes a duty on the Government to raise awareness of the change. There's no such duty proposed in this Bill. Do you think that's right or should this committee be saying that there should be a similar duty imposed in Wales?

column1: Barry Hughes: I'm not sure it's for me to say whether there should be a duty or not. I can
column2: however
column3: say that I think the greater the level of awareness
column4: the more likely it is that the Act
column5: if passed
column6: will achieve its intentions.

column2: thank you. And
column3: in your written evidence
column4: you mentioned the fact that there's no indication of any plans for awareness raising in England and that if a person from England is being prosecuted in Wales as a result of this change
column5: a question could arise about the lack of knowledge about the different provisions that apply in Wales. Can I ask what approach the CPS currently takes in Wales if a law is unintentionally broken by someone who's come from outside the UK
column6: for example?

column1: Barry Hughes: It's straightforward: if someone comes to this country and commits an offence here—by this country
column2: I'd say England or Wales; I'd treat them as one for these purposes—if someone comes from abroad and commits an offence that isn't an offence in their country
column3: but is an offence here
column4: then I'm afraid that ignorance of the law is no defence. So
column5: raising awareness is important
column6: and I saw
column7: and I was pleased to see
column8: that the media publicity surrounding this proposed legislation
column9: which is now going through
column10: reached as far afield as New York and had widespread media coverage across England and Wales
column11: and I think the Government would be well placed here to take advantage of that willingness of the media to explore something
column12: which is potentially divisive
column13: and I think you've probably seen some of that. Anything like that is a good story
column14: and a good story gets out there
column15: which means you're more likely to make people aware of it.

column1: Question: How did the National Police Chiefs' Council help in out-of-court disposals?

Be concise and factual. If the information is not in the transcript

column1: What did Barry Hughes think about the infrastructure of out-of-court disposals?|Barry Hughes thought that the infrastructure can be built for a range of out-of-court disposals. It might be built by the Welsh Government, the police, and crime commissioners.|['Lynne Neagle AM: Thank you. Vikki.'
column2: ""Vikki Howells AM: Thank you. I've got one further series of questions around out-of-court disposals
column3: which you've already mentioned briefly. In your written evidence
column4: you say there's ongoing work exploring diversion rather than prosecution in respect of this Bill. Firstly
column5: could you tell us a bit more about the work that is being done to explore this as an option?""
column6: ""Barry Hughes: We've been working with the National Police Chiefs' Council. Their lead is deputy chief constable Sara Glen. She is responsible for developing the police approach to out-of-court disposals and simplifying the range of out-of-court disposals. There is quite a range
column7: and life would be simpler and clearer to have fewer types of disposal with more clarity about what each one of them involved. I must say
column8: this is primarily a matter for the police
column9: because there are a great many offences or reports of crime that do not reach the CPS because they are dealt with by way of an out-of-court disposal. Any case that the police refer to us for a charging decision is going to be something—. There's a document called the director's guidance on charging
column10: which is issued by the director of public prosecutions
column11: which sets out offences the police may charge and offences the CPS may charge. Offences that the police refer to us for a charging decision will generally be offences where they feel that there should be a prosecution rather than an out-of-court disposal. There may be cases where it's genuinely very difficult to assess what's the best approach
column12: in which case we will have a conversation with them
column13: a meaningful conversation
column14: about what's the best way to approach that particular case. There will also be cases
column15: and we see these not that rarely
column16: where the police will bring a case to us for a prosecution on the basis that satisfies the evidential stage and satisfies the public interest stage
column17: and we take a different view on the public interest stage. So
column19: it involves a 15-year-old youth—we\xa0 think that diversion from the criminal justice system is a better disposal and we decide not to prosecute. We aren't responsible for administering\xa0the out-of-court disposal or indeed monitoring compliance with that disposal
column20: if
column21: for example
column22: it has conditions attached
column23: such as repayment of the damage caused to a window or a front gate. That's not our responsibility—that will fall to the police—but we can decide that an out-of-court disposal is a more appropriate disposal than a prosecution. Does that help?""
column24: ""Barry Hughes: The way I might see it is that
column26: policing's not devolved
column27: the CPS is not devolved—the way I might see this is that
column29: you could build an infrastructure that provides for a range of out-of-court disposals. You can't direct the police or the CPS to point people towards that
column31: if you build a good infrastructure
column32: it's more likely that people will be pointed in that direction.""
column33: ""Barry Hughes: Somewhere within Wales—Welsh Government
column35: the police working in partnership. It may be that the police and crime commissioners use some of their commissioning powers to work something up. I'm not the right person to answer that question.""

column42: however
column43: say that I think the greater the level of awareness
column44: the more likely it is that the Act

column53: ""Barry Hughes: It's straightforward: if someone comes to this country and commits an offence here—by this country
column54: I'd say England or Wales; I'd treat them as one for these purposes—if someone comes from abroad and commits an offence that isn't an offence in their country
column56: then I'm afraid that ignorance of the law is no defence. So
column59: and I was pleased to see
column60: that the media publicity surrounding this proposed legislation
column62: reached as far afield as New York and had widespread media coverage across England and Wales
column63: and I think the Government would be well placed here to take advantage of that willingness of the media to explore something

column66: and a good story gets out there
column67: which means you're more likely to make people aware of it.""]"|"You are an assistant that answers questions about meeting transcripts.

column1: Lynne Neagle AM: Thank you. Vikki.
Vikki Howells AM: Thank you. I've got one further series of questions around out-of-court disposals
column2: which you've already mentioned briefly. In your written evidence
column3: you say there's ongoing work exploring diversion rather than prosecution in respect of this Bill. Firstly
column4: could you tell us a bit more about the work that is being done to explore this as an option?

column1: Barry Hughes: We've been working with the National Police Chiefs' Council. Their lead is deputy chief constable Sara Glen. She is responsible for developing the police approach to out-of-court disposals and simplifying the range of out-of-court disposals. There is quite a range
column2: and life would be simpler and clearer to have fewer types of disposal with more clarity about what each one of them involved. I must say
column3: this is primarily a matter for the police
column4: because there are a great many offences or reports of crime that do not reach the CPS because they are dealt with by way of an out-of-court disposal. Any case that the police refer to us for a charging decision is going to be something—. There's a document called the director's guidance on charging
column5: which is issued by the director of public prosecutions
column6: which sets out offences the police may charge and offences the CPS may charge. Offences that the police refer to us for a charging decision will generally be offences where they feel that there should be a prosecution rather than an out-of-court disposal. There may be cases where it's genuinely very difficult to assess what's the best approach
column7: in which case we will have a conversation with them
column8: a meaningful conversation
column9: about what's the best way to approach that particular case. There will also be cases
column10: and we see these not that rarely
column11: where the police will bring a case to us for a prosecution on the basis that satisfies the evidential stage and satisfies the public interest stage
column12: and we take a different view on the public interest stage. So
column13: we might say—for example
column14: it involves a 15-year-old youth—we  think that diversion from the criminal justice system is a better disposal and we decide not to prosecute. We aren't responsible for administering the out-of-court disposal or indeed monitoring compliance with that disposal
column16: for example
column17: it has conditions attached
column18: such as repayment of the damage caused to a window or a front gate. That's not our responsibility—that will fall to the police—but we can decide that an out-of-court disposal is a more appropriate disposal than a prosecution. Does that help?

column1: Barry Hughes: The way I might see it is that
column2: clearly
column3: policing's not devolved
column4: the CPS is not devolved—the way I might see this is that
column5: within Wales
column6: you could build an infrastructure that provides for a range of out-of-court disposals. You can't direct the police or the CPS to point people towards that
column7: but
column8: if you build a good infrastructure
column9: it's more likely that people will be pointed in that direction.

column1: Summarize the discussion about unintended consequences.|Barry Hughes explained a number of unintended consequences questioned. The first one was about the isolated incidences in Wales, and the second came to the targets in terms of performance measure. The following concerns included malicious reporting, the European convention on human rights, low numbers of prosecutions, and a shortage of registered intermediaries.|[""Sian Gwenllian AM: Yes
column2: we've discussed some of these already
column3: but
column4: for example
column5: under the new law
column6: or the proposed law
column7: would one unintended consequence be that
column8: if someone living in Wales who can't use the reasonable punishment defence—would their life prospects be different compared to those people in England
column9: who will be able to use that defence? I think you've mentioned that in your written evidence.""
column10: ""Barry Hughes: Yes. Okay. A simple answer: if somebody in Wales is convicted—so
column11: if it goes towards the end of the spectrum that is serious
column12: which results in a prosecution—. It may be—the sort of circumstance I can see happening here is somebody who takes a principled stand and declines any form of out-of-court disposal and says
column13: 'Prosecute me'. We probably would end up prosecuting
column14: because it's a relatively serious offence. So
column15: let's say it comes to court and let's say they end up being convicted of assaulting their child—in circumstances that would not have happened in England—then they would have a criminal conviction they wouldn't have in England
column16: and that
column17: inevitably
column18: has an impact upon their life prospects. But I think
column19: along the road there
column20: there would have been an element of choice.""
column21: 'Sian Gwenllian AM: Okay. And do you think that that would be an isolated incident?'
column22: ""Barry Hughes: Yes
column23: truly
column25: an isolated incident. I've said before that I would be very surprised if we even had referrals that reached double figures on these cases. They're likely to be very limited. When the CPS was asked to conduct a survey across all of England and Wales—this was the review in 2007—it spanned just over a two-year period
column26: and there were 12 cases that were brought up at that stage. Now
column27: I have to say
column28: I don't think that's entirely reliable
column29: but it is indicative. We had a Freedom of Information Act request at one stage
column30: which threw up something like three cases in a year. So
column31: if you think about that as being all of England and Wales—and we make up about 5 per cent of the volume of criminal prosecutions nationally—you can see why I might say the numbers are likely to be small
column32: for the reasons we've explored about getting past the evidential stage into the public interest.""
column33: ""Barry Hughes: I have to say I think that extremely unlikely. In the CPS
column34: we don't have targets for securing convictions or not. Clearly
column35: we prosecute if we think that there's a reasonable prospect
column37: of conviction and it's in the public interest
column38: but we have no targets. And I would also say
column39: because the numbers here are likely to be so small
column40: any assertion of looking to meet targets—it's a tiny
column41: tiny fragment of a drop in the ocean.""
column42: 'Sian Gwenllian AM: What about—? There is a target for unsolved crimes
column43: or unsolved offences. What if they fall into that category? Is that an unintended consequence?'
column44: ""Barry Hughes: I'm talking about something I don't have great knowledge of here. There was
column46: a series of targets for the police that bore down upon cases that secure what was called a sanction detection
column47: which counted for Home Office figures. That disappeared some years ago. Some individual constabularies may still have targets
column50: we don't have a suite of national measures. The police are required to report against this
column51: but we don't have targets. And
column53: the police are much more sensible these days than they may have been 20 years ago
column54: in terms of trying to get cases charged in order to meet some notional target. It's much less of an issue than it ever was—much.""
column55: ""Barry Hughes: There is greater potential for it to increase. I think the numbers
column58: and dwarfed by the number of cases where we have to deal with the fallout between a relationship breakdown between partners—whether they be living within the same house or living in different houses. Regrettably
column59: there are times when children are used as part of this ongoing dispute. Getting into the subtleties of the father
column61: smacking the child in a way that was reasonable chastisement or was not reasonable chastisement is probably part of a much bigger piece here. I can see it potentially arising. It's not something that would cause me concern
column62: simply because we already have a well-developed approach to dealing with the way in which we evaluate the evidence from parties who may well have a particular position that they want to reinforce
column63: sometimes through exaggeration of basic facts and sometimes through fabrication.""
column64: 'Sian Gwenllian AM: Are there any other unintended consequences that come to your mind if we introduce this law?'
column66: I think we've had a pretty helpful canter through most of the circumstances here that might happen. And I can't think of anything else off the top of my head.""
column69: in a way—the European convention on human rights. Would not introducing the new law mean
column71: that Wales could get itself into difficulty because there is a breach of the human rights convention? And therefore England as well
column72: at some point.']"|"You are an assistant that answers questions about meeting transcripts.

column2: we've discussed some of these already
column3: but
column4: for example
column5: under the new law
column6: or the proposed law
column7: would one unintended consequence be that
column8: if someone living in Wales who can't use the reasonable punishment defence—would their life prospects be different compared to those people in England
column9: who will be able to use that defence? I think you've mentioned that in your written evidence.

column1: Barry Hughes: Yes. Okay. A simple answer: if somebody in Wales is convicted—so
column2: if it goes towards the end of the spectrum that is serious
column3: which results in a prosecution—. It may be—the sort of circumstance I can see happening here is somebody who takes a principled stand and declines any form of out-of-court disposal and says
column4: 'Prosecute me'. We probably would end up prosecuting
column5: because it's a relatively serious offence. So
column6: let's say it comes to court and let's say they end up being convicted of assaulting their child—in circumstances that would not have happened in England—then they would have a criminal conviction they wouldn't have in England
column7: and that
column8: inevitably
column9: has an impact upon their life prospects. But I think
column10: along the road there
column11: there would have been an element of choice.

column1: Sian Gwenllian AM: Okay. And do you think that that would be an isolated incident?

column2: truly
column3: I believe
column4: an isolated incident. I've said before that I would be very surprised if we even had referrals that reached double figures on these cases. They're likely to be very limited. When the CPS was asked to conduct a survey across all of England and Wales—this was the review in 2007—it spanned just over a two-year period
column5: and there were 12 cases that were brought up at that stage. Now
column6: I have to say
column7: I don't think that's entirely reliable
column8: but it is indicative. We had a Freedom of Information Act request at one stage
column9: which threw up something like three cases in a year. So
column10: if you think about that as being all of England and Wales—and we make up about 5 per cent of the volume of criminal prosecutions nationally—you can see why I might say the numbers are likely to be small
column11: for the reasons we've explored about getting past the evidential stage into the public interest.

column1: Barry Hughes: I have to say I think that extremely unlikely. In the CPS
column2: we don't have targets for securing convictions or not. Clearly
column3: we prosecute if we think that there's a reasonable prospect
column4: a realistic prospect
column5: of conviction and it's in the public interest
column6: but we have no targets. And I would also say
column7: because the numbers here are likely to be so small
column8: any assertion of looking to meet targets—it's a tiny
column9: tiny fragment of a drop in the ocean.

column1: Sian Gwenllian AM: What about—? There is a target for unsolved crimes
column2: or unsolved offences. What if they fall into that category? Is that an unintended consequence?

column1: Barry Hughes: I'm talking about something I don't have great knowledge of here. There was
column2: at one stage
column3: a series of targets for the police that bore down upon cases that secure what was called a sanction detection
column4: which counted for Home Office figures. That disappeared some years ago. Some individual constabularies may still have targets
column5: but
column6: as far as I'm aware
column7: we don't have a suite of national measures. The police are required to report against this
column8: but we don't have targets. And
column9: in my experience
column10: the police are much more sensible these days than they may have been 20 years ago
column11: in terms of trying to get cases charged in order to meet some notional target. It's much less of an issue than it ever was—much.

column1: Barry Hughes: There is greater potential for it to increase. I think the numbers
column2: again
column3: will be tiny
column4: and dwarfed by the number of cases where we have to deal with the fallout between a relationship breakdown between partners—whether they be living within the same house or living in different houses. Regrettably
column5: there are times when children are used as part of this ongoing dispute. Getting into the subtleties of the father
column6: say
column7: smacking the child in a way that was reasonable chastisement or was not reasonable chastisement is probably part of a much bigger piece here. I can see it potentially arising. It's not something that would cause me concern
column8: simply because we already have a well-developed approach to dealing with the way in which we evaluate the evidence from parties who may well have a particular position that they want to reinforce
column9: sometimes through exaggeration of basic facts and sometimes through fabrication.

column1: Sian Gwenllian AM: Are there any other unintended consequences that come to your mind if we introduce this law?

column2: I think we've had a pretty helpful canter through most of the circumstances here that might happen. And I can't think of anything else off the top of my head.

column1: Sian Gwenllian AM: Finally from me
column2: therefore—another issue
column3: in a way—the European convention on human rights. Would not introducing the new law mean
column4: at some point
column5: that Wales could get itself into difficulty because there is a breach of the human rights convention? And therefore England as well
column6: at some point.

column1: What did the group discuss about remote control style and design optimization?|Industrial Designer desired to integrate remote controls for different appliances into one. Marketing pointed out that such integration would lead to too many buttons, which was not user-friendly enough. Instead, Marketing suggested that a menu display should be incorporated. Project Manager and User Interface agreed and added that basic buttons could remain. User Interface and Industrial Designer refused the flip top, however, for it costs a lot. The team temporarily chose lightweight plastic to be the material.|['User Interface: Hmm hmm hmm .'

column1: Summarize the discussion about the user interface design.|The user interface designer introduced three concepts in the user interface - Google controller, fancy controller, and intelligent controller. The three meant that the product would be simple but powerful, attractive and recognizable, and loaded with speech recognition technology and gesture recognition technology. The first two were approved by the project manager, but the last one was seriously questioned. After a lot of discussions, the group finally decided to mix the Google controller and fancy controller with some simple vocal commands.|['Project Manager: {vocalsound} yeah .'

column1: Why did the user interface designer propose the concept of intelligent controller?|The user interface designer believed a controller with speech recognition technology and gesture recognition technology would be convenient when you couldn't find it. More importantly, although the feature was not one hundred percent reliable, it was a feature to distinguish the new product from traditional ones. And there's not enough motivation for users to replace their old controller with a new one if there's no key feature in the new controller.|[""Project Manager: {vocalsound} So let's start our second me meeting on {vocalsound} conceptual design .""

column1: Why did the project manager disapprove of the concept of intelligent controller?|The project manager put forward that the speech recognition wouldn't work when several persons wanted to change the channel at the same time, and the cost would surely rise if adding the two technologies. In response to that, the user interface designer said they would just cooperate with some research institute and the vocabulary was limited, so it wouldn't cost much. Then the project manager posed the language problem. The user interface designer answered they would have some language adaptations so the product could be used by people from all countries. Finally, there were still problems with the microphone and camera that were necessary for the two technologies.|[""Project Manager: {vocalsound} So let's start our second me meeting on {vocalsound} conceptual design .""

column1: Summarize the discussion about product industrial design.|The discussion about product industrial design covered three aspects —material, alimentation, and chip. The industrial designer suggested using wood instead of plastic to make the controller more fashionable and having buttons with LCD so that people could see the controller in dark. In terms of the alimentation, it would be good to have both the classical battery and solar energy alimentation. column1: What's the conclusion of the remote control style when discussing market research and adjustments due to new project requirements?|Overall, the model style was expected to be trendy and appealing. Marketing and Project Manager agreed on User Interface's design of a flip-screen. Marketing also hoped that the remote control would be slightly curved. User Interface added that the remote control would curl up to users' hands so that their thumbs did not have to press. The corporate logo would be put in the corner. column1: What were the statements discussed by the members?|Several members expressed their gratitude towards various groups such as first responders, working populations and different companies that have come together to help with the COVID crisis. Students whose education had undergone a radical change were highlighted and their fortitude appreciated. There was also a call to rally for disenfranchised groups such as rural residents, black lives movement and non-binary persons.|[""Mr. Paul Manly (NanaimoLadysmith
column2: GP): Mr. Chair
column3: it's an honour and a privilege to present a petition on behalf of the constituents of NanaimoLadysmith. People are concerned about gas fracking and the use of methane and the destruction that methane causes to our atmosphere and with climate change. They're calling on the government to commit to upholding the UN Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples and the Truth and Reconciliation Commission's calls to action by immediately halting all existing and planned construction of the Coastal GasLink project on the Wet'suwet'en territory
column4: and by ordering the RCMP to dismantle their exclusion zone and to stand down. They also call on the government to schedule nation-to-nation talks between the Wet'suwet'en nation and the federal and provincial governmentswhich is something that we're happy to see has been happening and I commend the government for that effortand to prioritize the implementation of the UN Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples.""
column5: 'The Chair: Next is Mr. Lamoureux.'
column6: ""Mr. Kevin Lamoureux (Winnipeg North
column7: Lib.): Mr. Chair
column8: like Canada
column9: Guyana is part of the Commonwealth
column10: and many constituents of Winnipeg North have raised the issue with regard to the presidential election back in March
column11: when it was being called into question. There have been some very positive indications in recent days
column12: but the petitioners are asking the Government of Canada
column13: and in fact all members of Parliament
column14: to be aware of what's taking place in Guyana
column16: to be advocates for democracy and make sure that we're being diligent in supporting what the people of Guyana want to see.""
column17: 'The Chair: Mr.Blanchet
column19: ""Mr. Yves-Franois Blanchet: That will be enough. I would be remiss if I allowed the Prime Minister to mislead people quite unintentionallyI say this in accordance with the Standing Orders. When we introduce a bill
column20: we discuss it at second reading
column21: we vote
column22: we continue to discuss it and we send it to committee. All that can be done very quickly. However
column23: we must be able to amend and improve this bill. That is how the normal Parliament works. The government doesn't like being in a minority situation. It behaves as if it were a majority government
column24: but it is not. Can we follow the real procedures of Parliament
column26: and then have a vote that is likely to suit the majority of members
column27: not just the Prime Minister?""
column29: my hon. colleague seems to completely forget that we are going through a pandemic. The COVID-19 crisis requires different actions on our part. That is why we provided the text of the bill to the opposition parties four days ago. We have been working with them for hours over the past three or four days to amend the bill
column30: if they had amendments to propose. That is how we are taking action to help Canadians quickly during this crisis
column31: and that is what we will continue to do.'
column33: you have the floor.'
column36: will the Prime Minister make a clear and direct commitment today to extend the CERB for families who need it?'
column38: we are introducing legislation this afternoon that will directly help Canadians living with disabilities
column39: will expand the scope of the wage subsidy and will increase the flexibility of the Canada emergency response benefit. We hope to be able to debate it.'
column40: 'Mr. Jagmeet Singh: Will the Prime Minister extend the CERB for families in need
column42: ""Mr. Jagmeet Singh: Mr. Chair
column43: a family that needs to buy groceries can't take those pretty words and buy groceries with them. We're asking the Prime Minister to extend the CERB for families in need. Will the Prime Minister do that
column47: we will continue to be there for Canadians in the right way. We are engaged with stakeholders
column48: with opposition parties and with Canadians to ensure that we continue to support them the way they need to be supported.'
column50: I can tell you what the right way is. Don from Burnaby sent me a note saying he's an arts worker and there is no forecast for his job to be reopened. He is now dependent on the CERB. He wants to go back to work
column51: but there's no work. He sent an email saying he's faced with a grim realityhis wordsand he's frightened that if the CERB runs out
column52: and it is planned to run out at the end of this month
column53: then he will have no way to afford to make ends meet. Will the Prime Minister extend the CERB so Don does not have to live in fear?""
column56: and as we have been saying from the beginning
column57: we will continue to be there to support Canadians who need it. The member opposite is not actually looking at the fact that we are proposing three significant helps for Canadians this afternoon. We are proposing to help Canadians with disabilities
column58: to expand the wage subsidy for more businesses and to create flexibility for the CERB. He doesn't even want to debate those things. He doesn't even want to be voting on them. Will the NDP allow us to move forward on these important measures for Canadians?""]"|"You are an assistant that answers questions about meeting transcripts.

column2: GP): Mr. Chair
column3: it's an honour and a privilege to present a petition on behalf of the constituents of NanaimoLadysmith. People are concerned about gas fracking and the use of methane and the destruction that methane causes to our atmosphere and with climate change. They're calling on the government to commit to upholding the UN Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples and the Truth and Reconciliation Commission's calls to action by immediately halting all existing and planned construction of the Coastal GasLink project on the Wet'suwet'en territory
column4: and by ordering the RCMP to dismantle their exclusion zone and to stand down. They also call on the government to schedule nation-to-nation talks between the Wet'suwet'en nation and the federal and provincial governmentswhich is something that we're happy to see has been happening and I commend the government for that effortand to prioritize the implementation of the UN Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples.

column1: The Chair: Next is Mr. Lamoureux.

column2: Lib.): Mr. Chair
column3: like Canada
column4: Guyana is part of the Commonwealth
column5: and many constituents of Winnipeg North have raised the issue with regard to the presidential election back in March
column6: when it was being called into question. There have been some very positive indications in recent days
column7: but the petitioners are asking the Government of Canada
column8: and in fact all members of Parliament
column9: to be aware of what's taking place in Guyana
column10: and as much as possible
column11: to be advocates for democracy and make sure that we're being diligent in supporting what the people of Guyana want to see.

column2: you have 43seconds left.

column1: Mr. Yves-Franois Blanchet: That will be enough. I would be remiss if I allowed the Prime Minister to mislead people quite unintentionallyI say this in accordance with the Standing Orders. When we introduce a bill
column2: we discuss it at second reading
column3: we vote
column4: we continue to discuss it and we send it to committee. All that can be done very quickly. However
column5: we must be able to amend and improve this bill. That is how the normal Parliament works. The government doesn't like being in a minority situation. It behaves as if it were a majority government
column6: but it is not. Can we follow the real procedures of Parliament
column7: do a proper job
column8: and then have a vote that is likely to suit the majority of members
column9: not just the Prime Minister?

column2: my hon. colleague seems to completely forget that we are going through a pandemic. The COVID-19 crisis requires different actions on our part. That is why we provided the text of the bill to the opposition parties four days ago. We have been working with them for hours over the past three or four days to amend the bill
column3: if they had amendments to propose. That is how we are taking action to help Canadians quickly during this crisis
column4: and that is what we will continue to do.

column2: you have the floor.
NDP): Mr.Chair
column3: will the Prime Minister make a clear and direct commitment today to extend the CERB for families who need it?

column2: we are introducing legislation this afternoon that will directly help Canadians living with disabilities
column3: will expand the scope of the wage subsidy and will increase the flexibility of the Canada emergency response benefit. We hope to be able to debate it.

column1: Mr. Jagmeet Singh: Will the Prime Minister extend the CERB for families in need
column2: yes or no?

a family that needs to buy groceries can't take those pretty words and buy groceries with them. We're asking the Prime Minister to extend the CERB for families in need. Will the Prime Minister do that
column3: yes or no?

column1: Right Hon. Justin Trudeau: Mr. Chair
column2: as I said
column3: we will continue to be there for Canadians in the right way. We are engaged with stakeholders
column4: with opposition parties and with Canadians to ensure that we continue to support them the way they need to be supported.

column2: I can tell you what the right way is. Don from Burnaby sent me a note saying he's an arts worker and there is no forecast for his job to be reopened. He is now dependent on the CERB. He wants to go back to work
column3: but there's no work. He sent an email saying he's faced with a grim realityhis wordsand he's frightened that if the CERB runs out
column4: and it is planned to run out at the end of this month
column5: then he will have no way to afford to make ends meet. Will the Prime Minister extend the CERB so Don does not have to live in fear?

column1: Right Hon. Justin Trudeau: Mr. Chair
column2: as I said
column3: and as we have been saying from the beginning
column4: we will continue to be there to support Canadians who need it. The member opposite is not actually looking at the fact that we are proposing three significant helps for Canadians this afternoon. We are proposing to help Canadians with disabilities
column5: to expand the wage subsidy for more businesses and to create flexibility for the CERB. He doesn't even want to debate those things. He doesn't even want to be voting on them. Will the NDP allow us to move forward on these important measures for Canadians?

They stressed for urgency and clarifications for when it would be provided to allow for the affected population to plan for the future. Many people depended on CERB for their living.|[""Mr. Jagmeet Singh: Mr. Chair
column2: a family that needs to buy groceries can't take those pretty words and buy groceries with them. We're asking the Prime Minister to extend the CERB for families in need. Will the Prime Minister do that
column3: yes or no?""
column4: 'Right Hon. Justin Trudeau: Mr. Chair
column5: as I said
column6: we will continue to be there for Canadians in the right way. We are engaged with stakeholders

column8: ""Mr. Jagmeet Singh: Mr. Chair
column9: I can tell you what the right way is. Don from Burnaby sent me a note saying he's an arts worker and there is no forecast for his job to be reopened. He is now dependent on the CERB. He wants to go back to work
column10: but there's no work. He sent an email saying he's faced with a grim realityhis wordsand he's frightened that if the CERB runs out
column11: and it is planned to run out at the end of this month
column12: then he will have no way to afford to make ends meet. Will the Prime Minister extend the CERB so Don does not have to live in fear?""
column13: ""Right Hon. Justin Trudeau: Mr. Chair
column15: and as we have been saying from the beginning
column16: we will continue to be there to support Canadians who need it. The member opposite is not actually looking at the fact that we are proposing three significant helps for Canadians this afternoon. We are proposing to help Canadians with disabilities
column17: to expand the wage subsidy for more businesses and to create flexibility for the CERB. He doesn't even want to debate those things. He doesn't even want to be voting on them. Will the NDP allow us to move forward on these important measures for Canadians?""

column1: Summarize what was said on the GBA+ analysis?|A committee member repeatedly asked why a GBA+ analysis was not conducted on the COVID-19 relief programs since this would have prevented rolling out inadequate programs for women. We are hearing from women who are pregnant or who have just given birth and are being left out or told to go back to work. When will this government stop letting Canadians down?""

column1: Summarize the discussion about the industrial design of the product.|The group reached the agreement to design an infrared-based controller because it was cheaper than a laser. Secondly, the industrial designer preferred a wireless remote control as it was easier to manage but the suggestion was doubted by the marketing and the project manager considering the cost and user requirements. Another thing was about the buttons. The marketing advised having less buttons because only ten percent of the buttons were actually in use and people tended to zap a lot.|['Project Manager: So

column1: Summarize the discussion about petitions fraudulence, tax evasion, violence handling and their supervisory.|Mr. Dan Albas asked about the handling of fraudulence by the Canadian government but Right Hon. Justin Trudeau, the Prime Minister, was saying that the government put giving support and help to Canadians in the first place. Then Mr. Gabriel Ste-Marie questioned the reason why the government supported the profiteers for tax evasion when implementing the large employer emergency financing facility. However, Right Hon. Justin Trudeau thought they were making plans to help workers to survive this pandemic and was always their priority to overcome. Hon. Candice Bergen required that how they were dealing with unopened mail at Service Canada and put out a violence case that why the Liberals were making this gun illegal and What the purpose of banning this particular farm rifle was. It was demonstrated by Hon. Bill Blair that many Canadians were murdered by these guns which was their explanation of banning guns.|[""Ms. Elizabeth May (SaanichGulf Islands
column2: GP): Thank you
column3: Mr. Chair. It's an honour to take the mike today
column4: with all colleagues here. It's good to see you all virtually and safe. Petitioners in my community point out in this petition
column5: which
column6: of course
column7: predates the pandemic
column8: that the family doctor shortage is severe in this country. Nearly five million Canadians lack a regular family doctor. This problem is particularly profound in more rural areas
column9: including
column10: as the petitioners reference
column11: the community in which I live
column12: Sydney
column13: British Columbia. We have a very significant crisis and a lack of family doctors. The petitioners call on the government to work with provinces and territories to find a collaborative
column14: holistic solution so that every Canadian has a family doctor and we address the family doctor shortage.""
column16: CPC): Good morning
column17: Mr. Chair. I'm presenting a timely petition today that emphasizes the concerns constituents in my riding of MissionMatsquiFraser Canyon have with the Liberal government's inherently flawed and undemocratic approach to firearms legislation and regulation. The petitioners call upon the Government of Canada to stop targeting law-abiding firearms owners; to cancel all plans to confiscate firearms legally owned by federally licensed RCMP-vetted Canadians; to focus taxpayer dollars where they will actually increase public safety
column18: which is on keeping at-risk youth from being involved in gangs and on anti-gang enforcement; and to provide our men and women in uniform at the Canada Border Services Agency with the resources they need to stop the flow of illegal guns into this country. Through this petition
column19: my constituents take issue with how the Liberal government continues to target law-abiding firearms owners instead of the gangs
column20: drug traffickers and illegal weapons smugglers responsible for the violence in our communities. They note that the use of the phrase military-style assault rifle is purely political posturing
column21: as the term is undefined in Canadian law. They also draw attention to the numerous inaccuracies about current firearms legislation and regulation""

The petitioners are asking that the Government of Canada not provide any financial assistance to Canadian airlines until they promptly provide full refunds for flights that were cancelled due to COVID-19. They are asking the same for any foreign airlines that fly to

column3: Mr. Chair. Today we've learned that federal workers have been told to ignore obvious signs of fraud when it comes to applying for government benefits. Can the Prime Minister confirm that 200
column4: 000 applications have been flagged as potentially fraudulent?

column1: Right Hon. Justin Trudeau (Prime Minister): Thank you
column2: Mr. Chair. Our priority from the beginning has been to make sure that Canadians get the support they need. We moved very quickly to get the Canada emergency response benefit out
column3: to get the wage subsidy out and to help Canadians in this unprecedented situation. We recognize there will be challenges
column4: and we are going to work through those challenges. Our priority every step of the way was to make sure we helped as many Canadians as possible.

column1: What did Mr. Gabriel Ste-Marie mean by saying that the Prime Minister continued to support the profiteers?|Mr. Gabriel Ste-Marie first asked the prime minister whether the government would outlaw what was immoral and then, put it precisely, made an example that a bank relocated its most profitable activities carried out in Canada and registered them in a subsidiary in the Bahamas, Barbados or another tax haven. column1: Summarize the discussion about Government support for the elderly and for vulnerable people.|During the pandemic of Covid-19, the government should fix this gap so that the single parents and their children could get the support they need. Also, matching funds and adequate housing should be given to support the affected in Canada. In addition, the elderly, one of the highest risk populations, had obtained extra funding from the government. Besides, vulnerable people like the disabled could gain more funding support and workers affected by the pandemic could also gain support.|['Ms. Jenny Kwan: That does not replace spousal support and child maintenance
column2: Prime Minister. Across the country there is no national standard to address the homelessness crisis amidst this pandemic
column3: leaving communities at heightened risk from COVID-19. Canadians who are homeless or living in substandard housing have no access to bathroom facilities for basic hygiene. Those living in crowded SROs and shelters cannot practise social distancing. The problem is particularly acute in my riding in the Downtown Eastside. While the B.C. government has implemented an initiative to house some of the homeless population in empty hotels in the short term
column4: support from the federal government is needed to secure permanent solutions post-COVID-19. Will the Prime Minister commit to providing matching funds and take the right to adequate housing seriously?'
column5: ""Right Hon. Justin Trudeau: I know that the honourable member wouldn't want to inadvertently mislead the House. The fact is
column6: the federal government almost immediately sent significant resources
column7: hundreds of millions of dollars
column8: to shelters across the country to enable them to create facilities
column9: including renting new spaces
column10: to be able to house homeless people without increasing the danger of the spread of COVID-19. I recognize there's always more to do
column11: but as we demonstrated with our national housing strategy
column12: we are serious about fighting homelessness and supporting vulnerable Canadians
column13: and we will continue to do that.""
column14: ""Ms. Jenny Kwan: The Prime Minister must know that the money the federal government sent is deficient. Many people still remain homeless
column15: and they are at risk. Cutting chronic homelessness by 50% over the next decade is not good enough
column16: and that is this Prime Minister's national housing strategy. Will the government stop just making empty promises and ensure that every Canadian has the right to housing? Will he top up the support for provinces to at least match their funds?""
column17: 'The Chair: The honourable minister.'
column18: ""Hon. Deb Schulte: My colleague is right. Seniors have faced increased costs due to the COVID-19 pandemic
column19: and our government today has responded to that with additional action. We announced a one-time
column20: tax-free payment of $300 for seniors eligible for OAS and an additional $200 for seniors eligible for GIS. This means there will be up to $500 for the most vulnerable seniors to help them with their financial security to get through this challenging time. Beyond this
column21: we announced $20 million to expand the new horizons for seniors program to kick-start initiatives and services that will help seniorsfor example
column22: to get grocery deliveries right to their door and to stay connected. We've worked tirelessly on this as well as on other recent measures like the GST credit to help the most vulnerable seniors. Thank you to my colleague for her advocacy.""

column1: What did Ms. Jenny Kwan mean by saying there was a gap between program making and its implementation?|Ms. Jenny Kwan gave an example that a single parent with four school-age children lost her spousal and child support due to COVID-19. That meant a complicated program delivered by the government that left many people behind, and more importantly, there was no action reacting to it. So Ms. Jenny Kwan called for a fixation for this gap and proposed that matching funding and adequate housing should be arranged for those who were affected.|['Right Hon. Justin Trudeau: Mr.Chair

column33: and we will continue to do that.""
column34: ""Ms. Jenny Kwan: The Prime Minister must know that the money the federal government sent is deficient. Many people still remain homeless

column1: What did the Canadian government do to support the elderly.|As one of the highest risk populations, the elderly's costs had gone up. Many seniors who were facing extra dispensing fees were already carefully budgeting before the pandemic. It was so important that the government be there to support them. The government announced a one-time, tax-free payment of $300 for seniors eligible for OAS and an additional $200 for seniors eligible for GIS. This meant there would be up to $500 for the most vulnerable seniors to help them with their financial security to get through this challenging time. Beyond this, they announced $20 million to expand the new horizons for seniors program to kick-start initiatives and services that would help seniors to get grocery deliveries right to their door and to stay connected.|[""Hon. Deb Schulte (Minister of Seniors): Thank you very much. There is definitely an interest in and support for our seniors. We've been working to support seniors since the very beginning of this pandemic. I've just had the opportunity to introduce additional measures today wherein we are introducing a one-time special payment for those who receive OAS.""
column2: 'Mrs. Stephanie Kusie: Nearly two months into living in some form of isolation
column3: watching their retirement savings take a hit and having to take additional health precautions due to the COVID-19 pandemic
column4: eligible seniors are set to receive a one-time payment of up to $500. Why does this government consistently undervalue seniors compared with everyone else?'
column5: ""Hon. Deb Schulte: I just want to make sure that my honourable colleague remembers that we have already given a GST top-up of almost $375 for single seniors and over $500 for couples. This is in addition to what we've just done today where
column6: as you said
column8: ""Mrs. Stephanie Kusie: According to Abacus Data
column9: 69% of Canadians feel that there will be a second wave in the pandemic
column10: and 52% of Canadians believe that there is a shortage of medical equipment
column11: including personal protective equipment. Given these surprising figures
column12: what is the government's plan to bring in enough personal protective equipment
column13: should there be a second wave of the pandemic?""
column14: ""Hon. Anita Anand (Minister of Public Services and Procurement): Our government is aggressively buying life-saving equipment and supplies that Canada needs
column15: from a diverse range of suppliers around the world and here at home. We're working directly with businesses across the country to rapidly scale up domestic production capacity to meet current and future needs. At this point
column16: our primary focus is on front-line health care professionals
column17: but we are also exploring federal government assistance in areas of essential services so that PPE exists where workers need it. We are following public health guidance on this issue in looking to see where we can best assist.""

column23: to get grocery deliveries right to their door and to stay connected. We've worked tirelessly on this as well as on other recent measures like the GST credit to help the most vulnerable seniors. Thank you to my colleague for her advocacy.""
