column1: Summarize the discussion about Government support for energy resources and tourism and funding in green economy and small businesses.|Since Quebec was Canada's biggest producer of hydroelectricity, renewable energy sharing through an energy corridor was very essential for different areas in Canada. And as a hard-hit sector, tourism needed much support from the Canadian government. The government was going to protect the tourism-based economy by investing in tourism infrastructure and upgrades to ensure Canada's tourist regions would be ready when the economy reopened. When it came to the green economy, the government now gave priority to the virus and making through this disaster. Also, they paid much attention to the small businesses and carried out measures to help them out.|[""Hon. Seamus O'Regan: Mr. Chair
column2: Canada's oil sector provides jobs for more than 576
column3: 000 people
column4: including 11
column5: 000 indigenous people
column6: in every part of Canada. It is essential that we support those businesses. It is essential that we support the many indigenous people who work in our oil and gas sector
column7: particularly in Alberta and Saskatchewan. We have provided supports for those businesses
column8: and we will continue to do so
column9: also keeping in mind that in many of these communities the importance of public health and safety is foremost in our minds.""
column10: ""Mr. David Yurdiga: Mr. Chair
column11: western Canada oil storage is under extreme pressure. If thermal projects such as SAGD are shut down
column12: those facilities could be lost forever. If the global oil markets remain oversupplied into the summer and industry must shut down production
column13: what is the government's plan to ensure Canada's energy security and the economic future of the oil sands with the potential shutdown of oil production?""
column15: we have worked with industry and with provinces on every front to ensure the stability of the oil and gas sector of our country. We have concentrated on workers. We need the workers in our oil and gas sector in order to lower emissions and achieve a greener economy. We need their determination and their ingenuity. We need to make sure that their jobs are held whole. Therefore
column16: we are looking after workers and we are looking out for companies that hold onto those jobs for those workers.""
column17: ""Mr. David Yurdiga: Mr. Chair
column18: the government's assistance package for the Canadian oil and gas industry provides some hope to the industry. The lack of detail and action has led to some challenges. Can the minister clarify? On a medium-sized energy company's eligibility
column19: if the company is in default to financial institutions
column20: does it still qualify for the business credit availability program?""
column21: 'The Chair: The honourable minister has the floor.'
column22: 'Hon. Jonathan Wilkinson (North Vancouver
column23: Lib.): Thank you
column24: Mr. Chair. Thank you very much for the question. Certainly at this time
column25: Canadians are most particularly focused on ensuring that support is provided so that they can put food on the table and pay their rent. We are starting to focus on the relaxation measures in many provinces and territories in Canada. That is the primary focus of the government
column26: as it is of Canadians. Certainly as we move forward
column27: we need to be thinking about the kind of society and economy that we want to create for the future. In that context
column28: we need to learn lessons coming out of this experience
column29: and certainly we need to ensure that we are addressing challenges that are on the horizon
column30: including the challenge of climate change. Those are conversations that will need to be had as we move beyond this phase of the crisis
column32: the focus is clearly on combatting the virus.'

column2: first of all
column3: we share the member's concern that small businesses be supported. That's why we've moved forward with a number of measures that are designed to be of assistance. With respect to rent support

column5: rent and landlord-tenant relations are under provincial jurisdiction. At every opportunity I talk to the provincial finance ministers to encourage them to get engaged there. column1: What was the current situation of the tourism sector and what was the government going to do?|The current economic situation could lead to the disappearance of Canada's tourism industry. And the pain would be felt by thousands of Canadians, who would have to find new jobs in order to survive. Let's work together to find ways to get this hard-hit sector moving again. Many people had lost their jobs and needed assistance from the government. That was why they were here, providing a helping hand at this difficult time so they could come out the other side.|[""Mr. Dan Albas: That's not what I'm asking here
column2: Mr. Chair. The Conservatives supported the legislation that allowed those supports to go through. What we are asking about is fraud. All along we've been told fraud would be detected through audits after the fact
column3: and we expect that to happen. Can the Prime Minister at least confirm that this will happen?""
column4: ""Right Hon. Justin Trudeau: When we made the determination that we needed to move quickly to help Canadians
column5: we knew there would be a need to clean up after the fact
column6: to go after fraudulent cases. We will do that. Our priority now and in the coming months is to ensure Canadians get the support they need
column7: and our economy comes roaring back. That's what we're focused on.""
column8: ""The Chair: We'll now continue with Mr.Ste-Marie.""
column9: ""Mr. Gabriel Ste-Marie (Joliette
column10: BQ): Mr.Chair
column11: yesterday
column12: the Prime Minister announced the large employer emergency financing facility. That's good. What's even better is that he announced that the loans would be tied to conditions. One of those conditions forces companies not to resort to tax evasion or tax avoidance through tax havens. Excellent! Unfortunately
column13: I quickly became disillusioned because it is more about abusive tax evasion and avoidance. Basically
column14: we're talking about fraudsters. There are no conditions that would allow us to tighten the screws on profiteers. Companies that legally take advantage of tax havens to avoid paying their taxes will have access to the large employer emergency financing facility. Why does the Prime Minister continue to support the profiteers?""
column16: we will always be there to counter tax evasion and tax avoidance. It's a priority of our government. There is no tolerance for tax evasion and tax avoidance. In the current situation
column17: our priority is to help workers across the country who could lose their jobs or who have lost their jobs. That's why we are introducing measures that support workers
column18: who will continue to be our priority.""

column23: Maine
column25: Nova Scotia. What is the government planning to do to help the ferry to survive and to resume service next season
column26: if the borders remain closed this summer?""

column28: and particularly in the Atlantic region. In light of the new funding for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency
column30: I will be happy to work with him and with the leaders of the tourism sector.""
column33: Mr. Chair.'

column1: What did the Canadian government do to help small businesses out?|They shared the member's concern that small businesses be supported. That's why they've moved forward with a number of measures that are designed to be of assistance. With respect to rent support, they were encouraging landlords to support this measure. Obviously, rent and landlord-tenant relations were under provincial jurisdiction. At every opportunity Hon. Bill Morneau talked to the provincial finance ministers to encourage them to get engaged there. They would continue to support small businesses. It allowed for small businesses to significantly reduce their rent and for landlords to be protected with up to 75% of the rent. It was a sound program and would require the provinces to step forward and enforce it.|[""Hon. Bill Morneau (Minister of Finance): Thank you
column2: Mr.Chair. We know that our approach has to help small and medium-size companies
column3: but also large companies in order to provide a bridge to the end of the crisis. In our opinion
column4: that is very important. It will protect the jobs of Canadians and the future of our economy. That's why the Large Employer Emergency Financing Facility is very important. That said
column5: we know that it is necessary and important to impose conditions. Yes
column6: we do want to make sure that the facility is available for companies that are going to continue to support our economy
column7: to protect their employees
column8: and to make a significant contribution to our communities. That is why we have attached a number of major conditions to our approach. We will have more details on the subject in the coming days. We established from the outset that we had to impose conditions on executive compensation. That is very important. We are going to consider the rules and conditions that are needed in order for the facility to be available to the companies
column9: the operations and the employees. Of course
column10: conditions are required to ensure that the facility is available for operations
column11: not for dividends or share buybacks
column12: for example. We will impose conditions of that kind. We also want to make sure that we are aware of the situation the companies are in. For example
column13: we want to be sure that they are not engaged in tax evasion.""

When will the government help small businesses whose landlords refuse to be team players during this pandemic?""

column22: first of all

It allows for small businesses to significantly reduce their rent and for landlords to be protected with up to 75% of the rent. We think it is an excellent program. It will require the provinces to step forward and enforce it.""

column1: Summarize the discussion about things including fishing and tourism, oil and gas affected by the Covid-19.|During the pandemic, the lobster fishery was being negatively affected and was facing losses of up to 95% of its Asian markets. Many fishermen had their wives, their sons, their uncles or their fathers working for them, and sometimes it was the whole family on the boat. Moreover, the tourism season is already deeply affected by COVID-19. A number of industries, businesses and festivals were having to deal with considerable losses of income. As for oil and gas, western Canada oil storage is under extreme pressure. If thermal projects such as SAGD are shut down, those facilities could be lost forever. The oil and gas sector was suffering through two crises --COVID and the effects of a global price war.|[""Hon. Bernadette Jordan (Minister of Fisheries
column2: Oceans and the Canadian Coast Guard): Thank you
column3: Mr. Chair. I thank my colleague for that very good question. We know that the fish and seafood sector has been extremely adversely affected because of COVID-19. We've started to put measures in place to address the issue with the $62.5 million for processors
column4: as well as to make sure that the CERB is available for seasonal workers as well as people who have run out of their fishery EI
column5: but we know that more needs to be done. The fishery enterprises are uniquely structured
column6: which is why we're looking at measures to address the concerns they have. I'm working with my provincial colleagues
column7: as well as my caucus colleagues.""

column13: their uncles or their fathers working for them
column14: and sometimes it's the whole family on the boat. Can the minister explain what the government's plan is to support fishermen who do not fit into any actual program and who desperately need direct financial help from the federal government to survive?""

column1: What did the government do to help the fishing industry?|The fish and seafood sector had been extremely adversely affected because of COVID-19. They've started to put measures in place to address the issue with the $62.5 million for processors, as well as to make sure that the CERB is available for seasonal workers as well as people who had run out of their fishery EI, but they knew that more needs to be done. The fishery enterprises were uniquely structured, which was why they were looking at measures to address the concerns they had. Because of the unique structure of fishing enterprises, they were not eligible for many of the supports they had put in place. They had made changes to the CERB to make sure that people who ran out of the fishers EI were eligible as well as seasonal workers.|[""Mr. Gord Johns (CourtenayAlberni
column2: NDP): Thank you
column3: Mr. Chair. It's a huge honour to table e-petition 2512
column4: which was signed by 1
column5: 198 petitioners
column6: primarily from the province of Nova Scotia. The Province of Nova Scotia invited multinational companies to scope out and develop expansive open-net salmon farming operations. The petitioners cite that the expansion would increase environmental degradation
column7: as seen in similar aquaculture operations in British Columbia
column8: Newfoundland
column9: Norway
column10: Vietnam and elsewhere in the world. It also
column11: they cite
column12: would pose risks to native fish stocks
column13: pollute coastal ecosystems
column15: and threaten established fisheries and tourism operations. They also raise concerns that open-net fish farming would not create significant employment and would undermine existing lobster and other fisheries. They are calling on the government to uphold Bill C-68 and species-at-risk legislation
column16: protect our oceans
column17: ban expansion of open-net finfish aquaculture in our oceans
column18: work to phase out any existing open-net fish farming operations currently in place and
column19: lastly
column20: invest in land-based
column21: closed-containment finfish aquaculture. I want to thank these petitioners for fighting for clean oceans
column22: for their local economy and for the well-being of Nova Scotia.""

column6: this is an ongoing project and we are having success for our front-line health care workers.

column1: The Chair: We'll now go on to the next question from Mr. d'Entremont.

column2: CPC): Thank you very much
column3: Mr. Chair. Ten weeks ago the Minister of Fisheries
column4: in responding to my question in question period
column5: acknowledged that the lobster fishery was being negatively affected by the COVID-19 pandemic and was facing losses of up to 95% of its Asian markets. Mr. Chair
column6: on April 28 I asked the minister what she was doing to support harvesters who were left out of the $62.5 million aid package. She mentioned that she was looking at sector-specific areas to make sure that the issues were addressed. Can the minister tell us what the government's plan is to directly support seafood harvesters?

column2: Oceans and the Canadian Coast Guard): Thank you
column3: Mr. Chair. I thank my colleague for that very good question. We know that the fish and seafood sector has been extremely adversely affected because of COVID-19. We've started to put measures in place to address the issue with the $62.5 million for processors
column4: as well as to make sure that the CERB is available for seasonal workers as well as people who have run out of their fishery EI
column5: but we know that more needs to be done. The fishery enterprises are uniquely structured
column6: which is why we're looking at measures to address the concerns they have. I'm working with my provincial colleagues
column7: as well as my caucus colleagues.

column2: most fishermen are not eligible for the wage subsidy program due to the stipulation that it cannot be used for employees who are related to their employer. Most fishing enterprises
column3: like farm enterprises
column4: are family oriented. Many fishermen have their wives
column5: their sons
column6: their uncles or their fathers working for them
column7: and sometimes it's the whole family on the boat. Can the minister explain what the government's plan is to support fishermen who do not fit into any actual program and who desperately need direct financial help from the federal government to survive?

column1: What did the stress faced by oil and gas?|The oil and gas industry was under severe strain. Over the past number of years, they had seen tremendous pressure on the federal government from anti-oil and gas lobby groups demanding that the oil sands be shut down. The federal Liberal government's response to the anti-oil lobby was the introduction of the Bill C-69, which would prevent any major oil and gas projects from being developed in Canada; and the oil shipping ban, Bill C-48, for the northern coast of British Columbia, which also had a negative effect on the oil industry. These two bills alone pushed over $200 billion of investment out of Canada, causing the Alberta economy to retract to recession levels. To compound Alberta's economic problems, we have an international oil price war and the COVID-19 pandemic, which caused a huge drop in demand for oil.|[""Hon. Seamus O'Regan (Minister of Natural Resources): Mr. Chair
column2: I'm happy that we were able to announce today some liquidity measures for large cap corporations in the oil and gas sector. These measures will provide them with the liquidity that they needed
column3: and this is also the liquidity that they asked for. It was on April 17 that we started liquidity measures for small and medium-sized businesses in the oil and gas industry
column4: and those are the ones in which 85% of workers are affected. Today's measures will complete that. I'm very happy that we've had such people as the Canadian Association of Petroleum Producers come out and say that this is what they asked for and this is what they need
column5: and we have produced what they need in order to ensure the future competitiveness of Canada's oil and gas sector.""
column6: ""Hon. Seamus O'Regan: Mr. Chair
column7: Canada's oil sector provides jobs for more than 576
column8: 000 people
column9: including 11
column10: 000 indigenous people
column11: in every part of Canada. It is essential that we support those businesses. It is essential that we support the many indigenous people who work in our oil and gas sector
column12: particularly in Alberta and Saskatchewan. We have provided supports for those businesses
column13: and we will continue to do so
column14: also keeping in mind that in many of these communities the importance of public health and safety is foremost in our minds.""
column16: western Canada oil storage is under extreme pressure. If thermal projects such as SAGD are shut down
column17: those facilities could be lost forever. If the global oil markets remain oversupplied into the summer and industry must shut down production
column18: what is the government's plan to ensure Canada's energy security and the economic future of the oil sands with the potential shutdown of oil production?""
column19: ""Hon. Seamus O'Regan: Mr. Chair
column20: we have worked with industry and with provinces on every front to ensure the stability of the oil and gas sector of our country. We have concentrated on workers. We need the workers in our oil and gas sector in order to lower emissions and achieve a greener economy. We need their determination and their ingenuity. We need to make sure that their jobs are held whole. Therefore
column21: we are looking after workers and we are looking out for companies that hold onto those jobs for those workers.""
column22: ""Mr. David Yurdiga: Mr. Chair
column23: the government's assistance package for the Canadian oil and gas industry provides some hope to the industry. The lack of detail and action has led to some challenges. Can the minister clarify? On a medium-sized energy company's eligibility
column24: if the company is in default to financial institutions
column25: does it still qualify for the business credit availability program?""
column26: 'The Chair: The next question will go to Ms. May.'
column27: ""Ms. Elizabeth May: Thank you
column29: colleagues. It's lovely to see all of you. My first question is directed to the Prime Minister. It's a higher-level abstraction. As we all know

column31: and the quest for a vaccine is all-consuming globally. However
column32: people who think about this issue and the question of the power structure and profit motive
column33: particularly Dr. Matthew Herder of the Health Law Institute at Dalhousie University
column34: are questioning this model. We know that Jonas Salk never sought a patent on his polio vaccine. Can we ensure that public dollars for finding a vaccine will result in a product that is shared globally
column38: I want to thank the member for her question. Our approach has been very clear when it comes to science. We have an open science model
column39: and we're working with different partners and different jurisdictions to help develop vaccines and look at countermeasures and other therapeutics. Our goal is to make sure that we do so in a collaborative fashion
column40: because this is a global pandemic
column41: but make no mistake: If it's Canadian ingenuity and Canadian IP that's driving it
column42: we want to support them as well.""]"|"You are an assistant that answers questions about meeting transcripts.

column1: Hon. Seamus O'Regan (Minister of Natural Resources): Mr. Chair
column2: I'm happy that we were able to announce today some liquidity measures for large cap corporations in the oil and gas sector. These measures will provide them with the liquidity that they needed
column3: and this is also the liquidity that they asked for. It was on April 17 that we started liquidity measures for small and medium-sized businesses in the oil and gas industry
column4: and those are the ones in which 85% of workers are affected. Today's measures will complete that. I'm very happy that we've had such people as the Canadian Association of Petroleum Producers come out and say that this is what they asked for and this is what they need
column5: and we have produced what they need in order to ensure the future competitiveness of Canada's oil and gas sector.

column2: Canada's oil sector provides jobs for more than 576
column3: 000 people
column4: including 11
column5: 000 indigenous people
column6: in every part of Canada. It is essential that we support those businesses. It is essential that we support the many indigenous people who work in our oil and gas sector
column7: particularly in Alberta and Saskatchewan. We have provided supports for those businesses
column8: and we will continue to do so
column9: also keeping in mind that in many of these communities the importance of public health and safety is foremost in our minds.

column2: western Canada oil storage is under extreme pressure. If thermal projects such as SAGD are shut down
column3: those facilities could be lost forever. If the global oil markets remain oversupplied into the summer and industry must shut down production
column4: what is the government's plan to ensure Canada's energy security and the economic future of the oil sands with the potential shutdown of oil production?

column2: we have worked with industry and with provinces on every front to ensure the stability of the oil and gas sector of our country. We have concentrated on workers. We need the workers in our oil and gas sector in order to lower emissions and achieve a greener economy. We need their determination and their ingenuity. We need to make sure that their jobs are held whole. Therefore
column3: we are looking after workers and we are looking out for companies that hold onto those jobs for those workers.

column2: the government's assistance package for the Canadian oil and gas industry provides some hope to the industry. The lack of detail and action has led to some challenges. Can the minister clarify? On a medium-sized energy company's eligibility
column3: if the company is in default to financial institutions
column4: does it still qualify for the business credit availability program?

column1: The Chair: The next question will go to Ms. May.

column2: Mr. Chair. Thank you
column3: colleagues. It's lovely to see all of you. My first question is directed to the Prime Minister. It's a higher-level abstraction. As we all know
column4: we're being told we need a vaccine
column5: and the quest for a vaccine is all-consuming globally. However
column6: people who think about this issue and the question of the power structure and profit motive
column7: particularly Dr. Matthew Herder of the Health Law Institute at Dalhousie University
column8: are questioning this model. We know that Jonas Salk never sought a patent on his polio vaccine. Can we ensure that public dollars for finding a vaccine will result in a product that is shared globally
column9: openly
column10: and is not for profit?

column2: I want to thank the member for her question. Our approach has been very clear when it comes to science. We have an open science model
column3: and we're working with different partners and different jurisdictions to help develop vaccines and look at countermeasures and other therapeutics. Our goal is to make sure that we do so in a collaborative fashion
column4: because this is a global pandemic
column5: but make no mistake: If it's Canadian ingenuity and Canadian IP that's driving it
column6: we want to support them as well.

column1: Summarize the discussion about detailed design of the remote control.|There were two main parts in the detailed design. Firstly, the prototype presentation, Industrial Designer presented the design on the wheel, the button, and the base of the remote control. Secondly, Marketing presented eleven points to be evaluated based on the findings in marketing trend reports and company strategy marketing. Besides, the group had a point calculation on each evaluation criterion.|[""Project Manager: 'Kay . Hmm . Okay everybody . Welcome to the detailed design meeting . Um and I think {disfmarker} looks like we've come up with some ideas . Um and we also talked about materials we'd use and what kind of chip would be necessary . Um so for later in the meeting I've done a a spreadsheet of production costs so we'll take a look at that . Um and see if it's changed at all from when we last discussed it . column1: Summarize the discussion about product appearance.|The user interface designer put forward that the basic colour would be red and yellow and there would be two basic shapes - circle and triangle, which was called a mushroom design. column1: Summarize the discussion about remote control style.|Marketing revealed that the younger target group preferred colourful objects and soft material. Then Industrial Designer introduced three casing possibilities: uncurved, single-curved and double-curved. column1: What did the meeting discuss about the funding issues?|The committee admitted that the funding issues brought more pressure on schools, especially after the new Act, for they would have to spend more in the light of it. It was pointed out that the government had not noticed the staff in the PRU, who required training. The committee was trying to communicate with Estyn and the Welsh Government for a broader range of measures to provide opportunities for schools and local authorities.|[""Lynne Neagle AM: Okay
column2: thank you. We've got some questions now on funding from Siân Gwenllian.""
column3: ""Sian Gwenllian AM: May I begin
column4: maybe
column5: with a question
column6: generally speaking—? We're all aware of the funding issues and the challenges of funding that face schools in general. So
column7: can this lead to more exclusions
column8: because additional learning needs have been hit in light of these challenges
column9: and then that the side-effects of that creates more exclusions?""
column10: ""Sharon Davies: In particular now with the new Act coming into force
column11: that's going to place more pressure on the system. In Torfaen
column12: we know that we have schools that are looking at their funding—they are behind
column13: and they have to make these hard choices. And sometimes
column14: they have to look at every aspect within the school in terms of their learners
column16: and that does place additional pressure on the schools.""
column17: 'Sian Gwenllian AM: Is the additional learning needs sector being adversely affected

column20: but certainly there's pressure

column23: 'Sian Gwenllian AM: But maybe we need to spend more in light of the new Act?'
column26: certainly.'
column27: 'Sian Hughes: What is your experience
column31: the Government doesn't think about the staff in the pupil referral units
column32: because we've gone back to the Government to tell them
column33: 'Right
column34: you've provided money to school staff
column35: but what about staff that need training—perhaps more than staff in the school sector?' And in fairness
column37: but perhaps it's not at the forefront of their minds when they're thinking of providing funding to the schools. So
column38: it's a little bit of an afterthought. But this will be needed in the future
column41: one of the things I think that has improved a lot is the networking within the PRU sector. We meet on a regular basis
column42: and that's nationally. And the EOTAS group meets regionally as well. So
column43: there's definitely a better sharing of practice. We put on some very
column44: very good conferences as one form of professional learning. But it's also important—. And we're talking about professional learning for any teacher or provider
column45: or it's sometimes the more informal training they receive by making visits
column47: to provision and also using the expertise that we do have within the sector to work more closely with our schools
column49: particularly around the curriculum. And I think this is the opportunity the new curriculum provides
column50: providing our staff have the funding to do that and the opportunities we need to be creating around that as well. But in the past
column51: there might well have been some staff who perhaps hadn't had those school experiences and vice versa.""
column52: ""Janet Finch-Saunders AM: Can I just ask you about transition arrangements
column53: because I know some of the issues that have arisen in my own constituency is when a pupil is in a PRU and then trying to get back into mainstream education? It isn't a clear
column55: going from one to the other—sometimes a child can find themselves at home because they're not able to get back into the school setting
column56: the main school setting. How are you addressing that?""
column59: I can only speak for ourselves. We've had a big investment of time
column60: and there will be money and through band B
column61: we're building a brand-new PRU provision in Swansea
column62: which will be open in January 2021. So
column63: we've recognised that
column64: so that we have our staff working very closely with the schools. There's an integration through a part-time timetable back into school
column65: and we continue to support them during that process. But then
column67: that support doesn't stop—that support continues
column68: and then there's a managed reduction in that support. And that's proven very successful.""
column70: I used to be a primary headteacher in England
column71: so we were looking at different models
column75: as a local authority—they had a PRU
column76: and they had discussions with their secondary schools
column78: whether to get rid of the PRU
column80: and give the money back into schools. But they looked at a partnership within the schools
column85: but there's got to be terms of reference'—not quite a service level agreement
column86: but the schools worked together as a partnership
column88: so that they couldn't keep moving the children around
column89: the learners around. It's looking at how well that worked. It started off really well
column90: but that was a few years ago
column91: so I don't know whether it's continued now. But that was a model that
column93: that local authority looked at to get more money into schools and to get schools
column95: to have that responsibility—that they didn't offload the learners elsewhere.""
column99: sorry. We do something similar in Swansea. We've operated this now for almost three years
column101: as opposed to 'delegate'—the money to secondary schools to try and give them some extra resource to manage the process

column112: who do need additional and bespoke support

column1: What did David Hopkins think of the new Act?|David Hopkins agreed with Sharon Davies that the new Act would exert more pressure on schools. However, he denied that the levels of the delegation would have any impact. Meanwhile, he suggested that it would be better for the schools' headmasters and local authorities to look at the new Act more constructively, for it would be beneficial for the post-16 sector.|[""David Hopkins: Yes
column2: sure. The delegation levels are already very high in most authority areas
column3: and we've got agreements in place with the Government to make sure that more money
column4: or as much money as possible
column5: is devolved to schools. So
column6: I don't think that's a direct factor. I think the factors that really affect exclusions
column7: which is where I think the question came from: you've got the very narrow measure at the end of key stage 4 attainment
column8: which I think has put pressure on some schools
column9: certainly
column10: and headteachers have felt that—sometimes excluded
column11: or otherwise put into another school as a consequence
column12: which is regrettable
column13: but that's what's happened. And on the additional learning needs side
column14: whilst the Minister has currently made some more money available
column15: if we look at experiences that have happened in England
column16: in particular
column17: because there are direct parallels there with legislation
column18: we know from those experiences that ALN funding has become increasingly under pressure—there have been big issues around tribunals
column19: to the point where local authorities at one point almost gave up going to tribunals
column20: because they were losing them time and time again. So
column21: there are financial pressures there
column22: but I don't think the levels of delegation have any impact on that.""
column23: 'Sian Gwenllian AM: Okay. But just the pressures coming in with the new Act et cetera could mean more expulsions.'
column24: ""Sian Gwenllian AM: Yes. I just want to discuss a little about the curriculum as it stands
column25: and thinking about transferring to a new curriculum
column26: of course. What are the challenges? I'll begin with the WLGA
column27: in general
column30: what are the challenges to ensure that EOTAS learners have access to a broad and balanced curriculum
column31: and that there are learning opportunities that are appropriate for them? What are the challenges associated with that?""
column32: ""David Hopkins: In general terms—. You differentiate there between EOTAS and PRUs. PRUs: clearly
column33: we know that they are following a set curriculum; they are inspected; they are under the control of the local authorities. So
column34: we're happy and content that that is moving along and that the balance is there. Where home tuition is provided through the local authority
column37: there should be safeguards there to make sure that that quality assurance takes into account what the pupil is receiving. You can't always guarantee what then happens in the home. As you say
column38: particular things happen there
column39: and they may not get that. But that's a matter the authority has got to be aware of and tackle. It's more difficult where
column41: it's being provided by a third party that's been commissioned. The commissioning arrangements should ask for those things to be put into place; it's all about the monitoring then. But that's a very general
column42: broad-brush answer. I couldn't give you a definitive one of what's happening across Wales. My colleagues can probably tell you what's happening in their localities
column43: and that would be helpful. But in general: PRUs
column45: we'd be satisfied; home tuition that is commissioned and managed through the local authority
column47: we would be satisfied; other areas
column48: we would not be able to give a definitive answer on
column50: 'Sian Gwenllian AM: And does that worry you?'
column53: ""David Hopkins: Of course it's a concern. If you can't guarantee quality in any shape or form for a young person
column56: Chair. It's really around support. It follows on a little bit from what Siân was saying. Can I also just refer back to the point that David was making earlier on about ALN and the extent to which ALN support is available to learners in EOTAS? The information that we've had is that it's difficult enough in mainstream schools
column59: how can that be improved? What can we do to address that? The reason I'm saying that is there are particular needs of learners in an EOTAS setting—that's why they're there
column61: it's almost more important that that ALN provision follows them through.""
column62: ""David Hopkins: If a child has additional needs
column63: of course they should be met
column64: whatever the setting. But I take your point. There's a possibility that—. Again
column65: going back to the previous question

column1: What did the meeting discuss about the networking within the PRU and the transition arrangements?|There had been improvements in the networking within the PRU, for they had national meetings on a regular basis, which could lead to a better sharing of practice. The PRU was planning to provide teachers with professional training. On the transition arrangement, the PRU was building a brand new provision in Swansea. The PRU would support students through a part-time timetable back into school. Besides, the support would not stop as soon as the students returned to school; the reduction of support would be managed.|[""Nick Williams: Well
column2: one of the things I think that has improved a lot is the networking within the PRU sector. We meet on a regular basis
column3: and that's nationally. And the EOTAS group meets regionally as well. So
column4: there's definitely a better sharing of practice. We put on some very
column5: very good conferences as one form of professional learning. But it's also important—. And we're talking about professional learning for any teacher or provider
column6: or it's sometimes the more informal training they receive by making visits
column7: joint visits
column8: to provision and also using the expertise that we do have within the sector to work more closely with our schools
column9: and vice versa
column10: particularly around the curriculum. And I think this is the opportunity the new curriculum provides
column11: providing our staff have the funding to do that and the opportunities we need to be creating around that as well. But in the past
column12: there might well have been some staff who perhaps hadn't had those school experiences and vice versa.""

column1: What was the major challenge of the transition of the excluded students?|The students coming to the end of their statutory education were facing the biggest challenge, for it would be far more difficult for them to go back into the mainstream education process when they turned 15 or 16, not to mention the transition into further education, such as colleges.|[""Lynne Neagle AM: Okay
column2: thank you. We've got some questions now on funding from Siân Gwenllian.""
column3: ""Sian Gwenllian AM: May I begin

column6: generally speaking—? We're all aware of the funding issues and the challenges of funding that face schools in general. So

column8: because additional learning needs have been hit in light of these challenges
column9: and then that the side-effects of that creates more exclusions?""
column10: ""Sharon Davies: In particular now with the new Act coming into force

column1: What did the meeting discuss about the pros and cons of local authoritative frameworks?|One of the advantages was that youngsters' voice could be heard in time if they showed the willingness to go back into school; the framework offered the excluded learners a cooling-off period. The disadvantage was mainly some individual schools' lack of capacity to organize and offer additional training. Monitor and evaluation systems of the EOTAS provision were supposed to be set up to ensure the education quality.|['Lynne Neagle AM: Okay. So
column2: to what extent
column3: then
column4: do local authorities have clear strategies for support and reintegration
column5: and a continuum of provision to meet the needs of learners who are either at risk of exclusion
column6: or disengagement?'

column8: we've just developed a behaviour and well-being strategy

column17: so that has a tiered approach
column19: or whichever

column22: but there will always
column23: unfortunately

Chair. It's really around support. It follows on a little bit from what Siân was saying. Can I also just refer back to the point that David was making earlier on about ALN and the extent to which ALN support is available to learners in EOTAS? The information that we've had is that it's difficult enough in mainstream schools
column3: but in an EOTAS setting
column4: it's particularly challenging. So
column5: how can that be improved? What can we do to address that? The reason I'm saying that is there are particular needs of learners in an EOTAS setting—that's why they're there
column6: quite often. So
column7: it's almost more important that that ALN provision follows them through.

column1: David Hopkins: If a child has additional needs
column2: of course they should be met

column5: we would know within
column6: say a PRU or any local authority commissioned or delivered tuition—whatever form that took—then those needs definitely should be being met. I can't tell you hand on heart whether they all are or not—I don’t know—but they should be. Once you get out of that very tightly regulated part of the system

column8: again

column11: but it becomes increasingly difficult. So

column1: What did the group discuss about the current trend and potential materials?|Marketing proposed that the fancy look and feel were more important than the functionality of the product. The fruit and vegetable theme was the current trend, and marketing himself preferred fruits to vegetables. Therefore, how spongy the material could be should be taken into consideration when choosing the materials. column1: What did the Industrial Designer say about component design?|Industrial Designer thought some parts needed custom design, and other parts should just use standard. For example, the case needed custom design to protect the remote and the locator, and the circuit board needed custom design as well, while the buttons and the wheels, radio sender and receiver were all standard parts. In addition, beeper or other noise things were needed as well for locating the remote. Rubber, plastic, wood and titanium were options of materials, but better not titanium. Regular chips were required if the iPod-style wheel button was used.|[""Industrial Designer: So I've been looking at the components design . Um . column1: What did the group discuss about technical issues of the project?|Industrial Designer introduced how the remote control worked and supposed that they should use infrared so that the remote control could communicate with most TV sets. He also proposed to use energy-friendly components and save the cost of circuit boards to develop elaborate lighting techniques. In order to prevent people from losing the remote control, the team decided to implement an audio signal. column1: What were the specific aspects of the framework of the curriculum that would be included in the primary legislation?|Kirsty Williams AM introduced that first of all, the four purposes would be set out in the legislation—as well as putting in learning and experience. Second, the government also intended to legislate for a number of the cross-curricular aspects like literacy, the numeracy and the digital competency. Third, a statutory provision for the 'what matters' statements would also be included.|['Claire Bennett: Yes.'
column2: 'Kirsty Williams AM: Yes
column3: January.'
column4: ""Lynne Neagle AM: Okay. Thank you. We've got some specific questions now on the legislation from Siân Gwenllian.""
column5: ""Sian Gwenllian AM: You've touched on the point that there's going to be some sort of change
column6: and you've mentioned in your paper to us that further specific aspects of the framework of the curriculum are going to be included in the primary legislation. We want to know what those aspects will be and what has made you change your mind.""
column7: ""Kirsty Williams AM: Yes
column8: as I said
column9: I think we've demonstrated that we're listening to people
column10: that there has been concern expressed about certainty and having a national approach on some of these issues
column11: and we have taken steps to address that and we'll continue to reflect
column12: but
column13: crucially
column14: we'll continue to reflect with our partners who are co-constructing this with us. And I think the important thing to remember is that it's not Ministers or civil servants that are necessarily drawing up these 'what matters' statements
column16: guided by experts in the field that are not teachers
column17: that have come up with these things.""
column19: thank you. Obviously

column22: ""Lynne Neagle AM: And we'll have an opportunity to influence it. Siân.""
column23: ""Sian Gwenllian AM: Moving on
column25: to the religious education and relationships and sexuality education
column26: I understand that you've had numerous responses to the White Paper surrounding this particular area. What are the main points that were raised with you and how do you intend to respond to what's been said?""
column27: ""Kirsty Williams AM: Well
column28: these two areas certainly have ensured that lots of people have responded. It's interesting that people are far more interested in what we may or may not do about these two subjects than maths
column32: but there we go; I guess it's the nature of the areas that we're talking about. With regard to religious education
column33: we had a significant number of people that have expressed concerns about our approaches towards RE that were set out in the White Paper. I think amongst the things that people have objected to were—. There were very mixed views on the inclusion of a range of faiths and world religions included in that area of learning. Many people said that there needed to be a much clearer and stronger—and in some cases exclusive—focus on Christianity
column34: as opposed to including other world religions and
column37: secular views or spiritual—spirituality rather than organised religion. There were people who thought that RE shouldn't be compulsory at all and therefore our proposals to ensure that RE was compulsory
column38: people objected to that
column39: on the other—. And there were many responses that were concerned about and emphasised the need to respect parents' views. So
column40: if a child's parents have certain views
column41: those are to be respected. Of those respondents that agreed that RE should be a compulsory part of the curriculum
column42: or were neutral—didn't express an opinion either way
column43: but were neutral on the question—the issues that they were bringing forward were: a need for learners
column45: to be prepared to be part of a diverse and multicultural society. So
column46: they wanted RE to be much more broad-based and encompassing of world views and world religions. They felt that that was an important part of preparing a young person to live in a world that is
column48: diverse with people of different views living in it. There is certainly a need to modernise RE; some people perceived the current curriculum as a bit old-fashioned. And also there was much feedback on making sure that the profession was ready to deliver a renewed
column50: those are the issues around religious education—""]"|"You are an assistant that answers questions about meeting transcripts.

column2: January.

column1: What value the government placed on different sectors?|Kirsty Williams AM suggested that Welsh Government had always been big supporters of WISERD (WalesInstitute of Social and Economic Research, Data and Methods). More research into Welsh education would always be needed. As a Government, all aspects of concerns of Welsh education should be taken into consideration as the government was planning the new curriculum. For instance,  empowering teachers to be able to be more flexible in what they teached their children actually gave the government an opportunity to deliver lessons that could be much more engaging and much more relevant to some of the school children than what they had at the moment.|['Kirsty Williams AM: Yes.'

column22: either as a backbencher or now as a Minister
column23: equality and principles of equity have always driven what I've tried to achieve. And I would never undertake a policy reform that I thought would lead to less equity in the Welsh education system. Closing the attainment gap is a core element of the national mission for education in Wales and we would not proceed with anything that we thought could lead to an exacerbation of an achievement gap.""
column25: that's really important. We don't want to do anything in pre-16 that stops people going on to be successful in post-16
column26: whichever route the child or young person decides to take. FE have been involved in every single AoLE and they're a part of the curriculum and assessment group. So

column28: I was very keen to take the opportunity to emphasise that any changes to qualifications should be a gateway to further study in FE
column29: whichever type of route the child took. But FE have been involved in this process from the very beginning.""

column8: either as a backbencher or now as a Minister
column9: equality and principles of equity have always driven what I've tried to achieve. And I would never undertake a policy reform that I thought would lead to less equity in the Welsh education system. Closing the attainment gap is a core element of the national mission for education in Wales and we would not proceed with anything that we thought could lead to an exacerbation of an achievement gap.

column2: that's really important. We don't want to do anything in pre-16 that stops people going on to be successful in post-16

column1: What did the WISERD research suggest about the distinction in schools?|Hefin David AM introduced that the WISERD research suggested that the senior management teams and classroom teachers would share different views towards the change since classroom teachers would be more sceptical. Kirsty Williams AM explained that classroom teachers were absolutely crucial to this, as a result, difficult step had been taken to delay the implementation of the curriculum to same some amount of time to make sure that it was not just school leaders but individual classroom practitioners who had the skills that they would need to make the most of the opportunity that the curriculum allowed them. To ensure this process, different accountability frameworks to the aims and objectives of the new curriculum would be incorporated.|[""Kirsty Williams AM: Well
column2: I think what the paper acknowledges is that there is no evidence that that will happen. These are 'coulds' and 'maybes' and things that we need
column3: as a Government
column4: to take into consideration as we plan this journey. There can't be any empirical research done at the moment because the curriculum isn't being delivered
column5: but I understand
column6: and we need listen to—. If there are concerns out there in the field that these are unintended consequences that we may fall into—that is the value of that piece of research that helps inform us. I have to say
column7: though
column8: the curriculum in itself is neither going to necessarily on its own hugely enhance equity nor detract from equity
column9: in the sense that the curriculum is what's taught in our schools. There is an opportunity
column10: I believe
column11: that empowering teachers to be able to be more flexible in what they teach their children actually gives us an opportunity to deliver lessons that could be much more engaging and much more relevant to some of our schoolchildren than what they have at the moment. What will make the curriculum a success for all of our children
column12: and I believe will have a bigger impact on children who are in danger of being left behind
column13: are the four enabling purposes of the curriculum. So
column14: the curriculum on its own can play a part
column15: but it will only be as good as the four enabling elements that surround it. And that is strong leadership of our schools that ensures that there is no segregation
column16: that has high expectation of all of our children
column17: and delivers a curriculum within that setting that meets the needs of the children there. Secondly: excellent teaching. In the end
column19: whatever its curriculum
column20: can exceed the quality of the people who stand in front of our children day in
column21: day out. So
column22: the curriculum can be the most exciting
column23: wonderful—and I think it is exciting and I think it's wonderful—it can be the most exciting
column25: but if teachers can't teach it effectively
column26: if their pedagogy is not excellent
column27: then the content itself—it won't work. Then we've got issues around assessment and accountability. So
column28: how do you assess how children are doing in your new curriculum? How do you understand how that pupil
column30: you know—who could be vulnerable for a whole host of reasons
column31: usually reasons outside of the school—? That pupil is vulnerable. How can you assess how that pupil is and move their learning along in an appropriate fashion? And then
column33: the well-being of the child. People sometimes say
column36: going soft'. But what we know is that we cannot expect children to learn unless we address issues around their well-being. But we also know that poor achievement is also detrimental to a child's well-being. There's been lots and lots of research done
column37: not in a Welsh context but in other systems
column38: where children are kept behind for a year. That has a massive impact on their well-being. So
column39: good achievement leads to good well-being
column40: but good well-being also leads to good achievement
column41: and you can't separate the two. So
column42: the curriculum on its own will not be enough. It is the four enabling objectives that sit around it
column43: and we have to be cognisant of the WISERD's research
column46: as we're doing our professional learning
column47: as we're planning well-being for our children
column48: as we think about assessment methods and how we develop a culture of strong leaders in our schools—and we have some
column50: but we need to do more to support them—it is that that will make the biggest difference
column51: not just the content of the curriculum on its own. Although I do believe the flexibility that we're allowing people will
column53: lead to a curriculum and more meaningful lessons for some children in schools who are in danger of disengaging because they don't understand why they're being asked to learn what they're learning
column54: they don't see the relevance of what they're learning to what they may want to do or how their lives are
column55: or they don't see themselves reflected. So
column57: they don't see themselves reflected in the curriculum that we're teaching at the moment. And
column60: if you want a child to thrive
column61: they have to see themselves and their community reflected in what they're learning in schools.""

column1: What did the meeting talk about the model of Scotland?|Hefin David AM asked about what lessons could be learned from the introduction of the Scotish curriculum. Kirsty Williams AM explained some of the challenges that they had faced in introducing their curriculum, including assessment and content, which had been a crucial part of the process. Also, professional learning, ensuring that the profession was properly prepared for the changes was an alert to the Welsh government. Steve Davies added that one of the critical elements was the extent to which assessment was considered at the outset alongside the curriculum content and it could be a fit for the new curriculum.|[""Steve Davies: As I said
column2: they're very forthright in sharing their learning and I think one of the critical elements was the extent to which assessment was considered at the outset alongside the curriculum content. So
column3: that was critical
column4: but we've embraced experts who were involved in that process who were part of our curriculum assessment group. So
column5: they feed in throughout—not 'don't do this because Scotland has done it'
column6: but they feed some of that learning into the system. As the Minister said
column7: we had seven other countries from across the world giving us feedback and input over four days as to where we can continue to look at what we're doing but also checks and balances against some of their experiences with this area of reform.""

column1: How would the money for supporting teachers help in the preparation of the implementation?|To answer Dawn Bowden AM's question, Kirsty Williams AM first indicated that the money was not an insignificant amount but the largest investment in professional learning since the history of devolution. column6: 'This is what we need to develop or to prepare for the implementation. The rest would be what would be normal professional development beyond that'?

column1: Steve Davies: Yes. There were 60 applicants from 170 previous pioneer schools. We've had 16—four per region. It was important that we engaged with the regions to get their view
column2: and we've had evaluation being carried out—
during the first term of work
column3: we asked them to really look at the curriculum as a whole—so
column4: take the whole curriculum guidance and then think
column5: 'How would I apply that in the school?
column6: Does it make sense?
column7: Can we work with it?
column8: What are the issues?
column9: What are the questions that arise for us for assessment?'
column10: and each of the schools produced a report setting out their reflections on
column11: 'If I were putting this into practice—'. So
column12: it's slightly different to the feedback we've had from other people
column13: which has been more
column14: 'Maybe you should emphasise this or change that wording' and kind of quite practical
column15: and really about how you would realise this curriculum in a school. That's been drawn together into an overall report
column16: drawing out the themes
column17: by Wavehill
column18: who are a kind of research company. It's been really useful
column19: and the innovation schools met as part of the workshops last week. Having 16 headteachers in a room talking about how they see this curriculum and the way in which they would practically engage with it has been invaluable
column20: in just making us think
column21: even with all the practitioners that have been involved
column22: 'How do we make this work for schools?'
column23: given that we've got schools and headteachers really engaging in the detail of how they would use it practically. So
column25: and they're continuing on that work now this term to keep making sure that what we're doing is something that schools can actually realise practically.

column1: What did the meeting discuss about the innovation schools?|Kirsty Williams AM pointed out that all schools that had previously been pioneers were invited to apply to morph into innovation schools, as the next phase. There would be both a downside and an upside for the programme of innovation schools. At this stage, it should be better to move away from the original 's AM concluded that pioneers were looking at specific aspects of the curriculum. In this case, school with a specific aspect of strength should be encouraged to apply.|[""Kirsty Williams AM: I think what's really important and what has been the strength of the process to date is that we are not doing this to our profession
column2: we are doing it with our profession. So
column3: in the spirit of co-construction
column4: the reflection on the feedback will continue to be primarily led by the existing infrastructure that we already had that got us to this stage at present.\xa0So
column5: Members will be aware that we've slightly changed the model. We had our pioneer school model and we have slightly refined that now. Pioneers were asked if they wanted to continue in that process and to put themselves forward
column6: and we've narrowed that down now to a smaller group of innovative schools. But above and beyond the innovative schools
column7: we looked at individuals who have specific expertise in subject areas
column8: and they're the first part of that process. So
column9: they met last week to begin looking at the feedback
column10: and we'll continue to use the processes that we have to reflect and refine. Are there big changes to the concept? No. Opportunities to do things better
column11: explain things better
column12: simplify where possible
column13: where we've been told that that needs to happen
column14: provide greater depth where we've been told that needs to happen—absolutely. We're definitely very alive and very willing to engage in those
column15: but in terms of the overall concept
column16: then no
column17: no significant changes.""

column21: ""Dawn Bowden AM: Okay. Thank you for that clarification. My final question in this section is just about how we are going to deal with the issue of teachers who are not trained in Wales. So
column22: teachers trained in England apply for jobs in Wales
column23: but they obviously haven't been trained in the new curriculum. How are we actually going to deal with that?""
column25: you're right—we will continue to have a system where teachers trained in Wales will teach in England and teachers trained in England or who have worked in England will come across the border
column26: as well as teachers from other parts of the world coming to teach in our schools. I think that that will continue to happen. Indeed
column27: when I'm feeling at my most confident and bullish about these issues
column28: I think Wales will be a really attractive place to be a teacher because of the autonomy that we will be giving to our professionals
column29: as well as an exciting new curriculum. So
column33: we will have people coming across the border to teach here because it'll be a great place to be a professional. Clearly
column35: programmes of study are already distinctive in Wales. We have a different exam board
column36: if you're teaching at a secondary level. So
column37: our programmes of study are already different and that does not preclude anybody from coming across to teach in our system from a different system. I believe that that's not a barrier to people continuing to do that. Clearly
column38: there may be pedagogical concepts in the new curriculum that perhaps somebody who had trained in a different system would not be completely au fait with
column39: but that is the ongoing role of professional learning within our school system
column40: because we've just talked about the two years' worth of money; in an ideal world
column41: if I was able to make long-term plans
column42: I think there will be an ongoing
column43: and there should always be an ongoing
column44: provision for professional learning in our classrooms. And this shouldn't just be about just getting people ready for the curriculum and then taking away professional learning budgets. One of the ways in which I think we can attract teachers to Wales is to send a very clear message— and actually attract people into the profession and keep them in the profession
column45: wherever they train—that you will have a career in teaching where you will be continually supported in your practice via professional learning. So
column46: I do not see that this is an insurmountable issue.""
column48: you'll still be recruiting on the basis of skills and adaptability and so on.""

column1: How was awareness and understanding of human rights embedded in the new curriculum?|Kirsty Williams AM explained that children's rights and human rights had been key considerations throughout the design, and this was currently set out in overarching guidance and the government continued to work with the children's commissioner's office to map the rights of the child across each area of learning and experience. And initial assessment from the children's commissioner's office had demonstrated that what was proposed in the new curriculum was a big stepforward. Also, the current existing output of that engagement and feedback had been drawn together into a report exploring learners' views about schools and learning, which was certainly a powerful contribution.|[""Kirsty Williams AM: Children's rights
column2: human rights—they've been key considerations throughout the design
column3: and this is currently set out in overarching guidance and we continue to work with the children's commissioner's office to map the rights of the child across each area of learning and experience. And I'm delighted that the children's commissioner took the time to write to me during the feedback phase to say that they were very pleased that their initial assessment demonstrates that what we're proposing is a big step forward.""
column4: ""Janet Finch-Saunders AM: Thank you. And how do you respond to the concerns expressed in the children's commissioner’s quarterly report of July 2019 that consultation materials for young people were not released until mid June
column5: allowing just over a month for young people to engage? And they said it was disappointing that a plan was not in place at the start of the consultation period.""
column6: ""Kirsty Williams AM: Well
column7: we undertook a specific programme of engagement with children and young people
column8: as I said at the beginning. We had over 20 events where focus groups of young children were involved and we had a number of children who took the opportunity to feed back via different mechanisms. The output of that engagement and feedback has been drawn together into a report exploring learners' views about schools and learning. It's a powerful contribution and I think will actually effect change
column9: especially in how the 'what matters' statements are worded.""

column1: Sian Gwenllian AM: I get that. That's why I don't understand why we're not actually going for it and showing how good we are through the PISA. But

column1: Kirsty Williams AM: There could well be a different decision

column1: What should be included in the implementation of the Welsh dimension?|Sian Gwenllian AM pointed out that the Learned Society of Wales had said that there should be a directory of resources to implement that Welsh dimension. Kirsty Williams AM introduced that there was a separate programme of work that was looking at resources needed to support the curriculum and it certainly would be a must.|['Sian Gwenllian AM: Okay. And
column2: in terms of the single continuum of learning with regard to the Welsh language
column3: how are progression steps and achievement outcomes in Welsh-medium schools going to work and how are they going to work in English-medium schools?'
column4: ""Kirsty Williams AM: Okay. Just on the Welsh dimension
column5: I think it's really important that whatever resources we have to support the Welsh dimension are really
column6: really
column7: really broad and not confined to specific areas. I was in Swansea University just this week
column8: looking at some of their Technocamp work that they're doing to help us with coding
column9: and we had an amazing conversation about the Welsh contribution to the computing industry. And so my expectation is that that isn't taught in a history lesson—that
column10: actually
column11: when children are learning about coding
column12: they get to hear that Welsh people have been at the forefront of developing this technology. So
column13: that's—. When I talk about a Welsh dimension
column14: I mean right the way across the curriculum
column15: and I think that's important. With regard to—. The continuum for language will have to be contextualised depending on the setting where a child is being taught. We have to recognise—. We have to recognise that
column16: and there will be progression points on that continuum that will be there to show progression both in Welsh language and in the English language
column17: and they have to be contextualised. We recognise that children learning Welsh in a Welsh-medium school
column18: their progressional on that point would be more speedy and quicker
column19: and by the end of primary school they would be in a very different position than a child that was learning Welsh in an English-medium school. Vice versa—we've had this discussion before—if a child is going into Welsh medium
column20: their progression in English perhaps from age three to seven would be very different from a child that was in an English-medium school
column21: although the expectation would be that by 11 they would be in the same position. So
column22: we have to contextualise that learning continuum depending on the medium of tuition with the school
column23: but recognising that it is a progression. It isn't a start and never get any further.""
column24: ""Sian Gwenllian AM: With regard to the creative thinking element of PISA

column26: why not participate in these tests?""

column1: Kirsty Williams AM: Okay. Just on the Welsh dimension
column2: I think it's really important that whatever resources we have to support the Welsh dimension are really
column3: really
column4: really broad and not confined to specific areas. I was in Swansea University just this week
column5: looking at some of their Technocamp work that they're doing to help us with coding
column6: and we had an amazing conversation about the Welsh contribution to the computing industry. And so my expectation is that that isn't taught in a history lesson—that
column7: actually
column8: when children are learning about coding
column9: they get to hear that Welsh people have been at the forefront of developing this technology. So
column10: that's—. When I talk about a Welsh dimension
column11: I mean right the way across the curriculum
column12: and I think that's important. With regard to—. The continuum for language will have to be contextualised depending on the setting where a child is being taught. We have to recognise—. We have to recognise that
column13: and there will be progression points on that continuum that will be there to show progression both in Welsh language and in the English language
column14: and they have to be contextualised. We recognise that children learning Welsh in a Welsh-medium school
column15: their progressional on that point would be more speedy and quicker
column16: and by the end of primary school they would be in a very different position than a child that was learning Welsh in an English-medium school. Vice versa—we've had this discussion before—if a child is going into Welsh medium
column17: their progression in English perhaps from age three to seven would be very different from a child that was in an English-medium school
column18: although the expectation would be that by 11 they would be in the same position. So
column19: we have to contextualise that learning continuum depending on the medium of tuition with the school
column20: but recognising that it is a progression. It isn't a start and never get any further.

column1: Sian Gwenllian AM: With regard to the creative thinking element of PISA

column1: Did the group think the remote control was competitive in the discussion of evaluation criteria of the remote control?|Marketing thought that the basic layout was mundane but the voice recognition was brilliant. column1: What did the group discuss about how much employers understood the meaning of Welsh bac?|They all agreed that most employers did not have a clear understanding of what Welsh bac means or what it includes, which was a big problem not only for employers, but also for parents and young people. Though some small engaged employers did understand it, the vast majority focused more on running the business without a clear understanding.|['Sian Gwenllian AM: Which is a big problem.'
column2: ""Dafydd Evans: Yes
column3: it's a huge problem
column4: but not only to employers
column5: but also to parents and young people
column6: of course.""
column7: ""Dr Rachel Bowen: And I think that that varies by size of employer as well. That
column8: certainly
column9: where there are larger employers
column10: who've got people who are able to follow policy developments across the education spectrum
column11: they may have more capacity to follow changes
column12: get up to date with how Welsh education is evolving. But we know that most employers in Wales are small or microbusinesses. And while there are lots of small engaged employers who have taken an interest and do understand
column13: the vast majority are more focused on getting on with the day-to-day running of the business. And that means it's quite a challenge to understand what is the Welsh bac
column16: when that's evolved over the past few years and there have been changes
column17: it would have been quite difficult to keep up to date with those
column19: ""Nick Brazil: Could I add to that? As do many of my colleagues\xa0within the colleges
column20: we have a number of employer boards
column21: which we regularly\xa0meet with—employers—and I cannot think back as to how many employers say to us
column22: 'That is what we require—the Welsh bac—to come and work within our industry.' Most of what they are questioning is the level of professional qualifications and the quality of skills within\xa0those professional sectors. Not many of them have indicated that the Welsh bac is providing the skills that they require. I think many of them believe in the vision that was set out for the Welsh bac\xa0initially
column23: but the Welsh bac\xa0has turned into quite a rigorous
column26: which is putting a lot of pressure on in terms of bureaucracy
column27: in terms of staff and the student getting all the information together at the end of the\xa0year
column28: and whether that's developing the skills that employers require is very questionable. And
column30: from the employer boards that we have
column31: very few of them understand\xa0the Welsh bac. They certainly don't mention the Welsh bac and
column33: are very much questioning the qualifications\xa0that have been provided to develop the actual professional skills needed within the industries.""
column34: ""Ed Evans: Can I give perhaps an employer's perspective on that
column36: but it's been interesting listening to what's been said here? About a year ago
column37: we bought the\xa0WJEC in to speak to our employers
column38: or a number of them
column39: just to explain to them what the Welsh bac was about—back to listening and about understanding
column41: and it just was not there at all. I could see that most of the employers\xa0there were really impressed with it once they understood what it was about and they saw the opportunities at a whole host of levels. We've kind of gone into an university discussion here
column42: but there are school leavers leaving at 16 or 18. The skills that they bring having gone through this process I think most of the employers could get
column44: they could understand—'I can see what that person can do.' But we've also seen it from university-educated people as well. They are a little bit too focused on the academic side of things. Those that bring a little bit of world experience
column45: a little bit of the Welsh bac-type of things
column46: just become far more rounded and useful people. I can understand why there's a certain obsession
column48: with the academic side of it
column49: but I think we lose that vocational bit at our peril
column50: and to a certain extent we probably haven't got it in many quarters anyway. So
column52: the Welsh bac helps to build that. Call it something else maybe
column53: but that's what it should do.""
column54: 'Julie Morgan AM: Right. And those skills that are learnt in the Welsh bac
column55: can they be learnt in any of the other qualifications? Because I know that Cambridge university said to us they thought
column56: in the four A-levels that they asked for
column58: ""Ed Evans: We do. There's a big range
column59: and some really high achievers coming into the sector as well. So
column60: it is about that mix. I think the discussion that I've had with our employers has been around the academic side of things
column61: if you like. The qualifications are well catered for. So
column62: it's almost a given somebody's been through that route. What isn't there is some of those softer skills
column63: but also some—. I was almost going to call commercial skills 'soft' there—.""
column65: ""Ed Evans: Commercial skills are hard skills
column67: very difficult to come by. So
column68: the Welsh bac starts to do some of those things at different levels. Again
column69: I'll come back to the input of businesses to support that delivery of commercial skills and so on
column70: but I think I probably made that point earlier. So
column71: I don't think it is a case of squeezing things out. There's clearly going to be different individuals who will cope better
column74: maybe guided as well by parents to a certain degree in terms of
column75: 'You do those four and forget about that nonsense there'
column77: but I can understand why that happens. So
column80: it's not a case of squeezing—. This should be seen as an important part of creating a rounded individual ready for employment. I guess that's what a lot of our employers saw the Welsh bac\xa0as being able to do. Whether that's a shared view is another matter.""
column81: ""Suzy Davies AM: That's great. Thank you.""
column82: ""Nick Brazil: Can I just add something to that? I think Ed's just said about the softer skills. Do the softer skills have to be developed through qualification? I think Kay mentioned a programme earlier on within her college. We run programmes as well. They're not qualifications
column83: but they offer the opportunity to develop those softer skills. So
column84: I think we're all in agreement about the development of the skills
column85: but does it need to be through a qualification?""]"|"You are an assistant that answers questions about meeting transcripts.
