column1: What did Ed Evans (director and secretary of the Civil Engineering Contractors Association) think about employers' understanding of Welsh bac?|Ed Evans thought employers did not understand it, but they would appreciate it if they do. This was particularly true for his own sector, the civil engineering sector, and particularly contracting sector. Because pupils usually did not have a very strong academic background in this sector, and Welsh bac gave them the opportunity to not pursue that much of academic, but tested them in terms of the challenges. Therefore, the growth of the Welsh bac would be valued at least for this sector.|[""Kay Martin: Certainly
column2: it's very similar
column3: and our employers want to make sure they get the right qualification. They're having enough headache getting around the differences with apprenticeships and the levy between England and Wales
column4: and changes to qualifications.\xa0But they want them to get their main qualification. So
column5: if you're an engineer
column6: they want to get the engineering qualifications and they\xa0want them to be literate
column7: numerate
column8: and they want them to have digital skills. And that isn't captured necessarily in the Welsh baccalaureate. And
column9: so
column10: the understanding is quite limited amongst the employers we work with.""
column11: ""Sian Gwenllian AM: Okay. And
column12: finally
column13: I know you've got strong views as an organisation.""

column1: Nick Brazil: Could I add to that? As do many of my colleagues within the colleges
column2: we have a number of employer boards
column3: which we regularly meet with—employers—and I cannot think back as to how many employers say to us
column4: 'That is what we require—the Welsh bac—to come and work within our industry.' Most of what they are questioning is the level of professional qualifications and the quality of skills within those professional sectors. Not many of them have indicated that the Welsh bac is providing the skills that they require. I think many of them believe in the vision that was set out for the Welsh bac initially
column5: but the Welsh bac has turned into quite a rigorous
column6: some would say demanding
column7: qualification
column8: which is putting a lot of pressure on in terms of bureaucracy
column9: in terms of staff and the student getting all the information together at the end of the year

column12: from the employer boards that we have

column15: are very much questioning the qualifications that have been provided to develop the actual professional skills needed within the industries.

column2: it's very similar

column9: so

column1: Summarize the views about how well the Welsh bac helped to prepare learners for employment.|One thing needing to be cleared was that Welsh bac was a combination of qualifications, but not just one qualification. To develop the employability skills was obviously a key part of it, but not all of it. It obviously worked well to help prepare for employment, but was not for everyone, because some people had to do the other things. It helped prepare some people, such as the A level students for university, but did not help health and social care people become more skilled and employable.|[""Nick Brazil: I think that is a very good question
column2: but I will go back to Ed's point
column3: which I think was a very important point
column4: which is that the initial vision for the Welsh bac—I think when we go back a number of years—was a really good
column5: good vision for the Welsh bac. It was going to be an overarching qualification that developed these skills
column6: and certainly employability skills
column7: and I think it's lost its way since then. It's become a qualification and all the realms around becoming a qualification
column8: and it's become very much focused on outcomes rather than necessarily skills. And that's what happens
column9: unfortunately. But I think what Ed said is absolutely right: if you get the engagement of the employers—. But you've got to listen to what Kay said as well: there are programmes already out there. So
column10: why are we focusing one way when there are already programmes that work extremely well? I will go to the enhanced programmes
column11: enhanced engineering and programmes that we are running within our college and that I know run in other colleges
column12: which are much
column13: much more focused on skills
column14: much more focused in linking with industry
column15: and they work extremely well. The actual progress of learners into employment is happening. So
column16: I think the question is: have we got programmes already in place
column17: and do we need another one on top? But the vision initially for the Welsh bac
column19: I will always be positive about. The vision was a good one.""
column20: ""Dafydd Evans: I'd like to expand on what Nick said. It's important for you to understand that although we always try and put the learner first
column21: funding does drive behaviours
column22: and the Welsh bac is fundable; Career Ready isn't. So
column23: yes
column25: but because we're so focused on qualifications and we will only fund qualifications
column26: that drives certain behaviours
column27: and\xa0I think you need as a committee to be very much aware of that.""
column29: but that was very useful information for us
column30: because bearing in mind what Nick Brazil said—that the vision of this was created as almost something that could have the status of something like a Duke of Edinburgh award without necessarily being a compulsory qualification; what was important was that the learners got the skills.\xa0However
column31: if getting the qualification is how you get the money
column32: then you can see why schools—well
column33: and indeed colleges—might be tempted to go for it. So
column35: 'Lynne Neagle AM: Okay. Have you finished? Janet.'
column36: ""Janet Finch-Saunders AM: Thank you. Good morning. What are your views on how well the Welsh bac
column38: helps to prepare learners for employment? We've spoken to quite a few learners
column39: and again we've had variable opinions coming back
column42: ""Dafydd Evans: I think that one of the problems is that there are a number of priorities. And one of the problems that we have is that we have a number of children coming in to the colleges
column43: and they need to resit their GCSEs—in maths
column44: English and Welsh. It's a valid priority for the Welsh Government for everyone to get a\xa0C grade in the core subjects. But that eats into the time that we have to teach young people. And so there's no room for everything in the curriculum somehow—no room in the funding or also in terms of the time and the capacity of the learner to be able to do that number of qualifications. So
column47: across the sector—. We've given priority to GCSE\xa0resits\xa0rather than doing the Welsh bac\xa0at present. So
column49: there are fewer and fewer doing 1 and 2 in the baccalaureate because they're resitting their GCSEs
column50: and there is much more use of the Welsh bac at level 3
column53: ""Nick Brazil: Can I just add to that? I think
column55: there's a misconception. The Welsh bac is a combination of qualifications; it's not just one qualification—it's a combination. So
column56: to develop the employability skills obviously is a key part
column57: and developing the skills for employment is a key part. But when you are focused
column59: on developing or achieving certain qualifications to make up the Welsh bac—for example
column62: plus your work for the Welsh bac
column63: which is the skills challenge certificate as well—that's a huge amount of work. And
column65: when you're trying to achieve outcomes—and we all get funded on the outcomes—that becomes the priority
column66: and sometimes then we lose the focus on the skills
column67: which are ultimately what were supposed to be part of the development for employability. So
column68: I think people lose the fact that the Welsh bac is a combination of things. And I think it was interesting
column69: the comment that was made about the Duke of Edinburgh—I thought that's something that we need to think about.""
column70: ""Kay Martin: If I could just say as well
column71: our job in the college is to develop skills and employable people
column72: and we use every tool in our box to do that. And
column74: there are lots of things that we do. The Welsh bac
column80: because some people have to do the other things. Some people doing the equivalent of three A-levels
column82: it's too big for them. As you say
column84: some of them with very few GCSEs
column85: or they haven't got literacy and numeracy skills
column86: they're being tested and many of them are below level 1 in terms of literacy and numeracy. So
column87: I think it needs to be reviewed
column88: to look at how we could make skilled and employable people. It helps prepare some people—the A-level students for university—but does it help my health and social care people become more skilled and employable? No

column2: and they need to resit their GCSEs—in maths
column3: English and Welsh. It's a valid priority for the Welsh Government for everyone to get a C grade in the core subjects. But that eats into the time that we have to teach young people. And so there's no room for everything in the curriculum somehow—no room in the funding or also in terms of the time and the capacity of the learner to be able to do that number of qualifications. So
column4: the priorities
column5: I think

column1: Nick Brazil: Can I just add to that? I think
column2: again
column3: there's a misconception. The Welsh bac is a combination of qualifications; it's not just one qualification—it's a combination. So
column4: to develop the employability skills obviously is a key part
column5: and developing the skills for employment is a key part. But when you are focused

column9: your main qualification

column2: our job in the college is to develop skills and employable people
column3: and we use every tool in our box to do that. And
column4: as I said earlier
column5: there are lots of things that we do. The Welsh bac
column6: where it works really well
column7: does help prepare them
column8: I think
column9: for employment

column1: Summarize Kay Martin (principal of Cardiff and Vale College) opinion on how well the Welsh bac helped to prepare learners for employment.|Kay Martin agreed with other people's opinion. They tried their best to help learners to develop skills and employable people. Welsh bac worked well for preparing employment for some people, but not for everybody. Because some people came to school with very few GCSAs, or were lacking literacy or numeracy skills. Kay Martin thought this needed to be reviewed, to look at how they could actually make skilled and employable people.|[""Lynne Neagle AM: Good morning

column1: Summarize Dafydd Evans' (chair of ColegauCymru) and Nick Brazil's (deputy principal) opinion on how well the Welsh bac helped to prepare for employment?|Dafydd Evans though that one of the problems was that there were a number of priorities. For example, there were a number of students who needed to resit their GCSE. It was important for everybody to get a C grade in those core subjects, but that would take some time from them teaching young people. Therefore, there were fewer and fewer doing level 1 and 2 in the baccalaureate because they were resitting their GCSEs. Nick Brazil added that Welsh bac was a combination of qualifications, and developing the employment was one of the key parts, but not all of it.|[""Lynne Neagle AM: Good morning
column2: everyone. Welcome to the Children
column3: Young People and Education Committee. We've received apologies for absence from Hefin David and there is no substitute. Can I ask whether there are any declarations of interest from Members
column4: please? No. Okay
column5: thank you. Item 2
column6: then
column7: is a further evidence session
column8: number four
column9: on our inquiry into the status of the Welsh baccalaureate qualification. I'm very pleased to welcome Dafydd Evans
column10: who is chair
column11: ColegauCymru
column12: and chief executive officer of Grŵp Llandrillo Menai; Kay Martin
column13: principal of Cardiff and Vale College
column16: Gower College Swansea
column17: also representing ColegauCymru; Dr Rachel Bowen
column18: director of policy and development at ColegauCymru; and Ed Evans
column19: who is the director and secretary of the Civil Engineering Contractors Association. Thank you all for attending. We're very pleased that you've been able to join us. If it's okay with you
column20: we'll go straight into questions
column21: and the first ones are from Siân Gwenllian.""
column22: ""Sian Gwenllian AM: Good morning. I'll be asking my questions in Welsh.""
column23: ""Nick Brazil: I think that is a very good question
column24: but I will go back to Ed's point
column25: which I think was a very important point
column26: which is that the initial vision for the Welsh bac—I think when we go back a number of years—was a really good
column27: good vision for the Welsh bac. It was going to be an overarching qualification that developed these skills
column29: and I think it's lost its way since then. It's become a qualification and all the realms around becoming a qualification
column30: and it's become very much focused on outcomes rather than necessarily skills. And that's what happens
column31: unfortunately. But I think what Ed said is absolutely right: if you get the engagement of the employers—. But you've got to listen to what Kay said as well: there are programmes already out there. So
column32: why are we focusing one way when there are already programmes that work extremely well? I will go to the enhanced programmes
column33: enhanced engineering and programmes that we are running within our college and that I know run in other colleges
column36: much more focused in linking with industry
column37: and they work extremely well. The actual progress of learners into employment is happening. So
column38: I think the question is: have we got programmes already in place
column39: and do we need another one on top? But the vision initially for the Welsh bac
column41: I will always be positive about. The vision was a good one.""
column42: ""Dafydd Evans: I'd like to expand on what Nick said. It's important for you to understand that although we always try and put the learner first
column44: and the Welsh bac is fundable; Career Ready isn't. So
column47: but because we're so focused on qualifications and we will only fund qualifications
column49: and\xa0I think you need as a committee to be very much aware of that.""
column50: ""Dafydd Evans: I think there's a real danger of us perhaps becoming overly critical here as well of the Welsh bac\xa0in terms of—I don't think it's perfect by a long way
column52: learners are getting some value out of that process. Certain learners in departments where they have really worked hard to contextualise the Welsh bac\xa0within the vocational area
column53: within the A-level subjects that the learners are doing
column54: are finding it very rewarding. So
column55: there are some very positive things coming out there. I think what we're suggesting is there may be even better ways of doing it and better ways of explaining to people what it's about.""
column56: ""Nick Brazil: On this point about the skills being developed
column57: I think that's debatable if all the skills that are supposed to be developed in the Welsh bac\xa0are being developed
column58: and that's why I think there's a need to relook at it to make sure those skills are being developed fully. But I will go back to the point that I think a comparable qualification is comparable as long as it achieves the right outcome for that particular learner. If you force a learner to do something that is not necessarily going to achieve the outcome that they require in their future
column59: is it the right thing to be doing for that learner? That's what my concern is.""
column60: ""Dr Rachel Bowen: I think the baccalaureate\xa0approach is best at producing independent
column61: inquiry-based learners who have the skills to look to teachers not as sources of information but just for guidance. That whole sort of approach about creating inquisitive young people with the skills that we've discussed
column62: that's a real positive. The chances are that we've lost some of that by trying to fit it into being a specific qualification. The approach is a positive one.""]"|"You are an assistant that answers questions about meeting transcripts.

column3: Young People and Education Committee. We've received apologies for absence from Hefin David and there is no substitute. Can I ask whether there are any declarations of interest from Members

column6: then
column7: is a further evidence session
column8: number four
column9: on our inquiry into the status of the Welsh baccalaureate qualification. I'm very pleased to welcome Dafydd Evans
column10: who is chair
column11: ColegauCymru
column12: and chief executive officer of Grŵp Llandrillo Menai; Kay Martin

column18: director of policy and development at ColegauCymru; and Ed Evans

column1: Sian Gwenllian AM: Good morning. I'll be asking my questions in Welsh.
Nick Brazil: I think that is a very good question
column2: but I will go back to Ed's point
column3: which I think was a very important point
column4: which is that the initial vision for the Welsh bac—I think when we go back a number of years—was a really good
column5: good vision for the Welsh bac. It was going to be an overarching qualification that developed these skills
column6: and certainly employability skills
column7: and I think it's lost its way since then. It's become a qualification and all the realms around becoming a qualification
column8: and it's become very much focused on outcomes rather than necessarily skills. And that's what happens
column9: unfortunately. But I think what Ed said is absolutely right: if you get the engagement of the employers—. But you've got to listen to what Kay said as well: there are programmes already out there. So
column10: why are we focusing one way when there are already programmes that work extremely well? I will go to the enhanced programmes
column11: enhanced engineering and programmes that we are running within our college and that I know run in other colleges
column12: which are much
column13: much more focused on skills
column14: much more focused in linking with industry
column15: and they work extremely well. The actual progress of learners into employment is happening. So
column16: I think the question is: have we got programmes already in place
column17: and do we need another one on top? But the vision initially for the Welsh bac
column19: I will always be positive about. The vision was a good one.

column1: Dafydd Evans: I'd like to expand on what Nick said. It's important for you to understand that although we always try and put the learner first
column2: funding does drive behaviours
column3: and the Welsh bac is fundable; Career Ready isn't. So
column4: yes
column5: there are options out there
column6: but because we're so focused on qualifications and we will only fund qualifications
column7: that drives certain behaviours
column8: and I think you need as a committee to be very much aware of that.

column1: Dafydd Evans: I think there's a real danger of us perhaps becoming overly critical here as well of the Welsh bac in terms of—I don't think it's perfect by a long way
column2: however
column3: learners are getting some value out of that process. Certain learners in departments where they have really worked hard to contextualise the Welsh bac within the vocational area
column4: within the A-level subjects that the learners are doing
column5: are finding it very rewarding. So
column6: there are some very positive things coming out there. I think what we're suggesting is there may be even better ways of doing it and better ways of explaining to people what it's about.

column1: Nick Brazil: On this point about the skills being developed
column2: I think that's debatable if all the skills that are supposed to be developed in the Welsh bac are being developed
column3: and that's why I think there's a need to relook at it to make sure those skills are being developed fully. But I will go back to the point that I think a comparable qualification is comparable as long as it achieves the right outcome for that particular learner. If you force a learner to do something that is not necessarily going to achieve the outcome that they require in their future
column4: is it the right thing to be doing for that learner? That's what my concern is.

column1: Dr Rachel Bowen: I think the baccalaureate approach is best at producing independent
column2: inquiry-based learners who have the skills to look to teachers not as sources of information but just for guidance. That whole sort of approach about creating inquisitive young people with the skills that we've discussed
column3: that's a real positive. The chances are that we've lost some of that by trying to fit it into being a specific qualification. The approach is a positive one.

column1: Question: Summarize Dafydd Evans' (chair of ColegauCymru) and Nick Brazil's (deputy principal) opinion on how well the Welsh bac helped to prepare for employment?

column1: Summarize the views to what extent they believe that universities understood the value of the Welsh bac.|They thought most universities did not understand, based on some experience they had with some of their learners that went to Russell Group universities. But this depended on the admission tutors and the areas that they were going. Some areas valued it more, but some others did not.|[""Nick Brazil: I think we've got to bear in mind when the students come to us—certainly when they're level 1
column2: level 2 learners—that a number of them have come from school and\xa0probably not done as well as they'd hoped at their GCSEs. Okay
column3: they've come to us
column4: they're trying to build themselves back up
column5: build their skills back up
column6: and adding another qualification on top
column7: adding the Welsh bac on top
column8: whether that's foundation or national
column9: on top of what they have to do
column10: which is a programme they've come and decided to do—think of the pressure that increases upon them. Plus the fact is that they are resitting; they're probably having to resit GCSE English and maths as well. That's a huge volume of work for a learner who's probably come from a\xa0low base to begin with and who hasn't achieved what they wanted to. The whole idea when we bring them in at that level is that we want to build their confidence
column11: build them up and
column12: hopefully
column13: eventually they will go to the stage where maybe the Welsh bac will be beneficial to them
column14: when they've potentially hopefully progressed to level 3. But I think it's questionable
column15: certainly at national and foundation. And the important point that Dafydd raised was that there's a lot of repetition there in school
column16: pre 16 to post 16 at those levels as well. So
column17: learners don't come in banging at the door saying
column18: 'We want to do the Welsh bac because it's exactly the same or very similar to what we did when we were in school.' They want to see some difference
column19: they want to see some progress
column20: and that's not necessarily the case in the foundation and national levels.""
column21: 'Dr Rachel Bowen: And we know that delivery in schools is of variable quality

column26: and

column28: Welsh universities are much more willing to recognise the bac. So
column30: it is less of a problem. But
column32: we do have students who are looking to go out to universities in England in the Russell Group
column33: and we're having the same experience there where there are differences between the policy that that university extols and what actually happens on the ground when students have interviews in those universities.""

column3: we've had a long track record of getting learners into top universities. About 20 per cent of our learners go to Russell Group universities

column7: obviously

column1: Kay Martin: Can I just mention as well that there's a bigger job in helping parents to understand that the only qualifications in the world are not A-levels? Perhaps you might want to do an engineering BTEC programme

column1: What did Nick Brazil (deputy principal) think of introducing a specialist teacher training qualification?|Nick Brazil thought the number of the skills and the number of challenges that were done within the Welsh bac were done very similarly within the vocational qualification. column1: What was needed for the transcripts?|Efforts by speaker fe008 are in progress to ensure that transcripts are clean (i.e. spell checked), channelized, and conform to set conventions regarding the coding of numbers, acronyms, and explicit comments (e.g. door slams, coughs, and laughter).
